revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} This is a listing of notable people born in, or notable for their association with, [[Aceh]].
__NOTOC__ {{compact ToC|side=yes|top=yes|num=yes}}
==A== * [[Mustafa Abubakar]], politician and formerly governor of the province of [[Aceh]] ([[Pidie Jaya Regency]])
==B== * [[Daud Bereueh]], military Governor of [[Aceh]] and leader of the [[Darul Islam (Indonesia)|Darul Islam]] rebellion in the province ([[Pidie Regency]])
==C== * [[Bachtiar Chamsyah]], politician in [[United Development Party]] (PPP) and Indonesian government minister under Yudhoyono presidency ([[Sigli]])
==D== * [[Cut Nyak Dhien]], [[List of National Heroes of Indonesia|National Hero of Indonesia]] ([[Aceh Besar Regency]]) * [[Jusman Syafii Djamal]], [[Minister of Transportation]] ([[Langsa]]) * [[Hilbram Dunar]], television presenter, radio broadcaster, master of ceremonies, and entertainer ([[Banda Aceh]])
==H== * [[Teuku Muhammad Hasan]], [[List of National Heroes of Indonesia|National Hero of Indonesia]], politician, The first Governor of [[Sumatera]] ([[Pidie Regency]])
==J== * [[Teuku Jacob]], paleoanthropologist ([[Peureulak]])
==M== * [[Cut Nyak Meutia]], [[List of National Heroes of Indonesia|National Hero of Indonesia]] ([[North Aceh Regency]])
==N== * [[Muhammad Nazar]], current Vice-Governor of [[Aceh]] ([[Pidie Regency]])
==P== * [[Surya Paloh]], media tycoon who owns the [[Media Indonesia]] daily newspaper and [[Metro TV]] ([[Banda Aceh]])
==R== * [[P. Ramlee]], famous Malaysian actor, movie director, musician and singer.
==S== * [[Hasballah M. Saad]], politician from [[National Mandate Party]] ([[Pidie Regency]])
==T== * [[Hasan di Tiro]], founder of the [[Free Aceh Movement|Free Aceh Movement (GAM)]] ([[Pidie Regency]])
==U== * [[Teuku Umar]], [[List of National Heroes of Indonesia|National Hero of Indonesia]] ([[West Aceh Regency]])
==W== * [[Cornelis Weber]], Dutch Olympic fencer ([[Banda Aceh]])
==Y== * [[Irwandi Yusuf]], current Governor of [[Aceh]] ([[Bireun]])
{{Aceh}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of People From Aceh}} [[Category:People from Aceh|*]] [[Category:Lists of people by place|Aceh]] [[Category:Indonesia-related lists|People from Aceh]]

page.title: List of people with Bell's palsy

revision.comment: Undid revision 862107919 by [[Special:Contributions/72.177.139.142|72.177.139.142]] ([[User talk:72.177.139.142|talk]]): no reliable source provided
revision.text:
Well-known people who have been diagnosed with [[Bell's palsy]] include: *[[Roseanne Barr]], American comedian and actress whose condition occurred as a child{{cite web|last=Tugend|first=Tom|url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/la_woman/article/roseanne_shares_secrets_and_jibes_20060324/|title=Roseanne Shares Secrets and Jibes |work=[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles]]|publisher=TRIBE Media Corp|date=March 23, 2006|accessdate=May 25, 2011}} *[[Stevie Benton]], bassist for Texas rock band [[Drowning Pool]](2007-12-06.) [http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=86265 "Drowning Pool bassist rushed to hospital, diagnosed with Bell's palsy."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018194310/http://www.roadrunnerrecords.com/blabbermouth.net/news.aspx?mode=Article&newsitemID=86265 |date=2008-10-18 }} ''Blabbermouth.net''. Retrieved on 2007-12-10. *[[Hafþór Júlíus Björnsson]], Icelandic professional strongman, actor, and former professional basketball player{{cite web|title=‘The Mountain’ Hafþór Júlíus Björnsson has Bell’s palsy|url=https://theconversation.com/the-mountain-haf-or-julius-bjornsson-has-bells-palsy-heres-what-it-means-75601|website=theconversation.com|accessdate=3 October 2017|date=April 6, 2017}} *[[Amy Brenneman]], American actress and producerhttp://www.momlogic.com/2010/03/lessons_from_my_hospital_stay_amy_brenneman.php *[[Pierce Brosnan]], Irish actor, film producer and environmentalist *[[Freddie Burns]], [[England Rugby|England]] and [[Leicester Tigers]] rugby playerhttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/article-3361421/Freddie-Burns-won-t-let-Bell-s-palsy-stop-playing-Leicester-Tigers-England.html *[[Scott Cairns]], American poet and theological writer whose condition occurred as a child *[[Jean Chrétien]], former prime minister of Canada(2000-11-28.) [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/1042917.stm "Jean Chrétien: Veteran fighter."] ''BBC News'' website. Retrieved on 2007-09-19. *[[George Clooney]], American actor, director, producer, and screenwriter(2006-02-16.) [http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0602/16/lkl.01.html "CNN.com Transcripts: Larry King Live, Interview with George Clooney."] ''CNN.com''. Retrieved on 2007-09-19. *[[Norm Coleman]], former United States Senator{{cite news |first= Mary Lynn |last= Smith |title= Norm Coleman confirms he has Bell's palsy |url= http://www.startribune.com/politics/state/58764557.html |newspaper= Star Tribune |date=2009-09-11 |accessdate=2009-09-12 }} *[[Alexis Denisof]], American actor[[Joss Whedon]]'s [[Angel DVDs#Season 5|Angel]] season 5 DVD commentary for ''[[Conviction (Angel episode)|Conviction]]''. *[[Glen Durrant]], BDO World Darts Championhttps://www.richardkirby.org/glen-durrant.html *[[Thomas C. Foley]], American politician and businessman; former U.S. Ambassador to Ireland{{cite news|url=http://www.norwichbulletin.com/newsnow/x995829189/Foley-Voters-ask-about-my-lack-of-smile |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130130162804/http://www.norwichbulletin.com/newsnow/x995829189/Foley-Voters-ask-about-my-lack-of-smile |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-30 |title=Foley: Voters ask about my lack of smile |work=Norwich Bulletin |date=2010-09-20 |agency=Associated Press }} *[[David Frum]], Canadian-American pundit[http://www.frumforum.com/note-to-readers] "frumforum.com". Retrieved on 2010-07-28. *[[Graeme Garden]], British comedy writer and performer, who has written about his experiences with the condition{{cite web|last=Garden|first=Graeme|title=How Cruel To Call It 'Bell's Palsy!'|url=http://www.bellspalsy.org.uk/graeme-garden.htm|publisher=Bells Palsy Association|accessdate=6 November 2012}}
Puttick, Helen. (2004-07-20.) [http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/spl/aberdeen/pioneering-research-looks-to-solve-mystery-and-ease-misery-for-bell-s-palsy-sufferers-1.80192 "Pioneering research looks to solve mystery and ease misery for Bell's palsy sufferers"] ''The Herald'' (Glasgow) *[[Allen Ginsberg]], American beat poet{{cite book |title=I celebrate myself: the somewhat private life of Allen Ginsberg |last= Morgan |first= Bill |year= 2006 |publisher= Viking|isbn= 0-670-03796-6 |page= 506|quote=One day in April he awoke to find the left side of his face paralyzed; it was a recurrence of his Bell's Palsy.}} *[[Tony Gonzalez]], American [[National Football League|NFL]] football playerGlazer, Jay. [http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/7207460 "Gonzalez happy to be alive."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016234724/http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/7207460 |date=2007-10-16 }} ''Fox Sports'' website. Retrieved on 2007-09-19. *[[Amy Goodman]], American journalist and authorGoodman, Amy. (2007-10-30.) [http://www.truthdig.com/report/item/20071030_for_whom_the_bells_palsy_tolls/ "For Whom the Bell's Palsy Tolls."] ''Truthdig.net''. Retrieved on 2007-12-10. *[[Jane Greer]], American actress{{cite book |title= Femme Noir: Bad Girls of Film|last= Hannsberry |first= Karen Burroughs |authorlink= |year= 1998 |publisher= [[McFarland & Company|McFarland]] |location= |isbn= 0-7864-0429-9 |pages= |url= }} *[[Trenton Hassell]], American basketball player for the [[New Jersey Nets]] of the NBA{{cite web |url= http://www.nj.com/nets/index.ssf/2008/11/nj_nets_make_room_in_the_infir.html |title= New Jersey Nets: Make Room In the Infirmary |accessdate=2009-02-05 |last= D'Alessandro |first= Dave |date= 6 November 2008 |work= The Star-Ledger |publisher= |quote= That was no ordinary virus: Trenton Hassell has Bell's Palsy,}} *[[Terrence Howard]], American actor{{cite web |url= http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2005/08/05/earlyshow/saturday/main763129_page2.shtml |title= Terrence Howard's Big Break |accessdate=2008-11-05 |last= |first= |date= 2005-08-25 |work= |publisher= [[CBS News]]}} *[[Armando Iannucci]], Scottish writer.{{cite web |url= https://twitter.com/AIannucci/status/7351609907 |title= AIannucci On Twitter |accessdate=2010-01-29 |date= 2010-01-03 |publisher= twitter.com}} *[[Angelina Jolie]], American actress and filmmaker{{cite news | last=Moniuszko| first=Sara M.| title =Angelina Jolie reveals Bell's Palsy diagnosis, breaks silence on divorce from Brad Pitt| newspaper =[[USA Today]]| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =26 July 2017 | url =https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2017/07/26/angelina-jolie-reveals-bells-palsy-diagnosis-breaks-silence-divorce-brad-pitt/513179001/| accessdate =26 July 2017}} *[[Anupam Kher]], Indian actor{{cite web | last= Akram | first= Ayesha Javed | title= Looking forward to seeing Lahore, says Anupam Kher | url= http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_15-5-2004_pg7_22 | date= 15 May 2004 | work= Daily Times |accessdate=2009-05-01 }} *[[Ralph Kiner]], American baseball player in the 1940s and 1950s(1998-04-01.) [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F03E1D61E3BF932A35757C0A96E958260 "Baseball: Kiner fighting Bell's palsy."] ''The New York Times'' Archives via nytimes.com. Retrieved on 2007-09-19. *[[Ella Koon]], Tahitian-born Hong Kong singer-actress.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1eDke2ww5Ks HK singer Ella Koon diagnosed with facial paralysis] *[[Curtis LeMay]], [[United States Air Force]] general and 1968 independent vice presidential candidate(2007) ''Nemesis: The Battle for Japan 1944-45'' by Max Hastings *[[Gordon Lightfoot]], Canadian singer{{cite news |first= |last= |title= Folksinger Lightfoot Performs at Orpheum |url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WE&s_site=kansas&p_multi=WE&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=119F2FC2CDF741A0&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |work= Wichita Eagle|date= June 22, 2007 |accessdate=2009-04-28}} *[[Martin Love]], Australian cricketer{{cite web | last= Dorries | first= Ben | title= Bulls gutted by withdrawals | url= http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,23330276-5003413,00.html | date= 2008-03-07 | publisher=Couriermail.com.au | accessdate=2009-05-01 }} *[[Joe Mantegna]], American actorByrne, Bridget. [http://archive.southcoasttoday.com/daily/08-01/08-23-01/c14ae132.htm Joe Mantegna returns as private eye, Spenser] Associated Press. 2001-08-23. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215091406/http://archive.southcoasttoday.com/daily/08-01/08-23-01/c14ae132.htm |date=February 15, 2009 }}{{cite news | url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-10-28/entertainment/ca-290_1_joe-mantegna | work=Los Angeles Times | date=1988-10-28 | title=Things changing in the acting character of Joe Mantegna | first=Kristine | last=McKenna }} *[[Pete Maravich]], American basketball player{{cite news|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/01/06/sports/sports-of-the-times-they-called-him-pistol.html|date=1988-01-06|title=Sports of the Times: They Called Him Pistol|first=George|last=Vecsey}} *[[Florence Mars]], American civil rights activist and author{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/29/us/29mars.html?pagewanted=print&_r=0|work=The New York Times|date=2006-04-29|title=Florence L. Mars, 83, Who Was Spurned for Rights Work, Dies|first=Nadine|last=Brozan}} *[[Tom McCarthy (ice hockey, born 1960)|Tom McCarthy]], Canadian [[National Hockey League]] player who played for the Minnesota North Stars and Boston Bruins.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/05/20/sports/sports-people-comings-and-goings.html|date=1988-10-28|work=The New York Times|title=Sports People: Coming and Going}} *[[Glenda McKay]], British actor *[[Danny Meyer]], American restaurateur in New York City; chief executive officer of Union Square Hospitality Group{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/07/magazine/danny-meyer-is-on-a-roll.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|date=2011-08-07|title=A Movable Feast: Danny Meyer on a Roll|first=Sean|last=Wilsey}} *[[Scarlett Moffatt]], British television personality{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/bells-palsy-symptoms-treatment-and-causes_uk_582eef3ce4b0c6c8bc156c6f|work=Huffington Post|date=2016-11-18|title=Scarlett Moffatt’s Battle With Bell’s Palsy: Symptoms, Treatment And Causes Explained|first=Natasha|last=Hinde}} *[[Kim Mulkey]], American basketball player and coach ([[Baylor Lady Bears basketball|Baylor University women]]){{cite news|url=http://espn.go.com/womens-college-basketball/tournament/2012/story/_/id/7752049/2012-women-final-four-baylor-coach-kim-mulkey-diagnosed-bell-palsy |title=Kim Mulkey has Bell's palsy |work=[[ESPN.com]] |date=March 29, 2012 |accessdate=March 29, 2012}} *[[Ralph Nader]], American politician{{cite book|title=Ralph Nader: A Biography|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group,|isbn=0313330042|page=101|author=Patricia Cronin Marcello|quote=The first blow to Nader came about when he developed Bell's palsy...}} *[[Cliff Pennington (baseball)|Cliff Pennington]], shortstop for the [[Oakland Athletics]]{{cite news | url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/dailypitch/post/2011/08/cliff-pennington-oakland-as-bells-palsy/1 | date=2011-08-02 | title=A's Cliff Pennington has Bell's palsy | last=Borelli | first=Stephen | work=USA Today }} *[[Jim Ross]], [[professional wrestling]] commentator for [[World Wrestling Entertainment|WWE]] and [[World Championship Wrestling|WCW]]{{cite web|title=J.R. suffers third Bell's palsy attack|url=http://www.wwe.com/inside/news/jimrossbellspalsyattack|publisher=WWE|accessdate=9 March 2015}} *[[Rick Savage]], bass guitarist for the British rock band [[Def Leppard]]{{cite news | url=http://www.rsvpmagazine.ie/rsvp-interview-with-def-leppards-rick-savage-and-wife-paige/ | work=RSVP Magazine | title=RSVP Interview with Def Leppard’s Rick Savage and Wife Paige | date=2013-03-23 | author=James }} *[[Tom Seaver]], Hall of Fame Major League pitcher[http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/mets/madden-tom-nearing-terrific-day-mets-legend-winning-battle-lyme-disease-article-1.1289293#ixzz2ZMsDLxA7NY Mets great and Hall of Fame pitcher Tom Seaver feeling better, winning his battle with Lyme disease] ''New York Daily News'' March 15, 2013[http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/baseball/mets/madden-mets-legend-seaver-set-all-star-game-pitch-article-1.1394430#ixzz2ZMpSpRN3 At 2013 MLB All-Star Game, Mets legend Tom Seaver, fighting back from Lyme disease and memory loss, ready for pitch] ''New York Daily News'' July 9, 2013 *[[Bernadette Sembrano]], Filipino newscaster, host of the medical program ''[[Salamat Dok!]]'' and anchor of ''[[TV Patrol Weekend]]''{{ cite news | url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/07/12/11/bernadette-sembrano-has-bells-palsy | date=2012-07-12 | title=Bernadette Sembrano has Bell's palsy }} *[[Ayrton Senna]], Brazilian [[Formula One]] racecar driver{{cite book |title= Remembering Ayrton Senna |last= Henry |first= Alan |authorlink= |author2=Townsend, John |year= 1994 |publisher= Weidenfeld & Nicolson |location= |isbn= 0-297-83450-9 |pages= |url= }} *[[Rahul Sharma (Indian cricketer)|Rahul Sharma]], Indian cricketer{{cite web|title=The man who stared adversity in the eye|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/indian-premier-league-2011/content/current/story/515696.html|work=Espn Cricinfo|accessdate=19 May 2011}} *[[Jamey Sheridan]], American actor whose condition was written into the show ''[[Law and Order: Criminal Intent]]''Owen, Rob. (2005-05-20.) [http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/05140/507385.stm "TV Q&A with Rob Owen."] ''Pittsburgh Post-Gazette'' via ''post-gazettenow'' website. {{For|Russian footballer|Magomed Yevloyev (footballer)}} {{use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Magomed Yevloyev |image = Евлоев, Магомед Яхьяевич (8 сентября 2007).JPG |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = 1971 |birth_place = [[Malgobek]], [[Chechen-Ingush ASSR]], [[Soviet Union]] |death_date = 31 August 2008 (aged 36–37) |death_place = |residence = |nationality = [[Ingushs|Ingush]] |alma_mater = |occupation = [[Journalist]], [[lawyer]] and [[businessman]] |years_active = |net_worth = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |children = |parents = |signature = |website = }}
'''Magomed Yakhyаvich Yevloyev''' (Магомед Яхьявич Евлоев; 1971 – 31 August 2008) was an [[Ingush people|Ingush]] journalist, lawyer, and businessman, and the owner of the news website [[Ingushetiya.ru]], known for being highly critical of [[Murat Zyazikov]], the President of [[Ingushetia]], a [[federal subject]] of Russia locating in the [[North Caucasus]] region.<ref>[http://ingushetiya.wordpress.com/2008/08/31/owner-of-site-ingushetiyaru-killed/ Owner of the news site "Ingushetiya.Ru", Magomed Yevloev], 31 August 2008</ref> Magomed Yevloyev is not to be confused with the Ingush rebel leader [[Akhmed Yevloyev]], who is also known as Magomed, or with the 20-year-old also named Magomed Yevloyev who is suspected of being a suicide bomber in the [[Domodedovo International Airport bombing]].
==Early life and education== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Screenshot of ingushetiya.ru.png|border|666px|thumb|Screenshot of Magomed Yevloyev's website www.ingushetiya.ru in 2005 (no longer operational; available via http://old.ingushetiyaru.org/news/6214.html)]] --> Magomed Yevloyev was born in the town of [[Malgobek]], [[Chechen-Ingush Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]] (now in the [[Republic of Ingushetia]], Russia) in 1971.<ref name=lentopedia>[http://www.lenta.ru/lib/14176029/ Евлоев, Магомед] collection of materials on [[Lenta.ru]] library {{ru icon}}</ref> In 1992, Yevloyev graduated from [[Saratov]] Law Institute (Саратовский Юридический Институт).<ref name=lentopedia/>
==Career== After graduation, Yevloyev began to work as a [[public procurator]] in Ingushetia. He soon became the Deputy Chief Procurator of Malgobek. In 1999, he was accused of complicity in the murder of Suleyman Tsechoyev, who was at that time imprisoned as a kidnapper. Allegedly Yevloyev had signed the permit allowing the murderers to take Tsechoyev from his cell. The accusations were not proven but Yevloyev resigned from his post as a prosecutor.<ref name=lentopedia/>
In 2001, Yevloyev founded the Moscow legal firm [[Infra-Yur]]. In 2008, the firm became [[Infra Holding]], a company which oversaw construction, fishing, legal firms, and security bureaus. It also controlled [[Infra North America]], a daughter firm operating in the United States. Yevloyev was the president of this holding.<ref name=lentopedia/>
Also in 2001, Yevloyev created the website "Ingushetia.ru". Originally there was no intention to make an opposition website; Yevloyev planned to host a neutral collection of materials on the history and culture of the Ingush people, without favoring any particular point of view. But he soon found that historical and cultural materials often included explosive political content as well, and the site became a source of political materials, such as information on the [[Second Chechen War]], counter-terrorist operations, the [[Ossetian–Ingush conflict]], and kidnappings and murders in Ingushetia. Many of these materials were highly critical of Ingushetia President Murat Zyazikov and his government.<ref name=lentopedia/>
In July 2007, the public procurator of Moscow's [[Kuntsevo]] municipality initiated a criminal case accusing Yevloyev of "inciting inter-ethnic hatred", though in the end Yevloyev was never indicted for any criminal activities. In October 2007, the Tsechoyev murder case was reopened and Yevloyev's family house in [[Malgobek]] was searched. After the search, Yevloyev's father, Yakhyu Yevloyev, convinced his son to publicly sever all ties with the Ingushetia.ru site, as it appeared to be too dangerous. Since then, the site has been controlled by an editorial committee chaired by Ibragim Kostoyev.<ref name=lentopedia/>
Yevloyev did not, however, completely withdraw from the politics of Ingushetia. He was one of the organizers of the ''I did not vote'' campaign, intended to expose mass [[voter fraud]] in Ingushetia during the [[Russian presidential election, 2008|2008 Russian presidential election]]. According to official data, 98% of eligible Ingushetia voters took part in the elections, almost all voting for [[Dmitry Medvedev]]. But Yevloyev alleged that less than half of registered voters had actually participated in the elections, and therefore sought to compile a list of people who could personally guarantee that they did not vote in the election. If the list proved to include more than 2% of Ingushetia's voting registry, it might constitute proof of massive election fraud.<ref name=lentopedia/>
Yevloyev also organized and financed a campaign collecting signatures calling for the removal of Ingushetia President Zyazikov, and the restoration of the previous Ingushetia president [[Ruslan Aushev]].<ref name=lentopedia/>
In the beginning of 2008, the office of the Ingushetia public procurator initiated hearings in Kuntsevo Court, demanding that access to the site Ingushetia.ru be restricted. According to the prosecutors, in an interview with Ingushetia businessman [[Musa Keligov]] hosted on the site, Keligov directly accused Zyazikov of connections with guerillas. The prosecutors argued that this material constituted [[libel]] as well as "public advocacy of extremist activity". In May 2008, the court issued an injunction demanding that Russian providers "limit access to the site by filtering its [[Internet Protocol|IP]] addresses". In June 2008, the court characterized the site as "extremist" and demanded its closure. The site was not closed. According to Ingushetia.ru's lawyer Kaloy Akhilgov, since the site is registered in the United States, it is therefore outside the jurisdiction of Russian courts. Akhilgov also stated that the decision is technically incorrect because it classifies the site under the heading "mass media" despite the fact that the site is not officially registered as such. Akhilgov added that they intended to appeal the court decision.<ref name=lentopedia/>
==Death== On 31 August 2008, Magomed Yevloyev was shot in the [[Temple (anatomy)|temple]] and killed while in police custody.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7590719.stm Ingushetia website owner killed], [[BBC News]], 31 August 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24272873-12377,00.html Kremlin critic found dead], ''[[The Australian]]'', 31 August 2008</ref><ref name=AP>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2008/08/31/international/i072332D67.DTL&tsp=1 Deputy says Russian police kill Web site owner], [[Associated Press]], 31 August 2008</ref> Weeks before his killing, it was rumoured that Magomed knew his life was in danger and he had planned on seeking [[political asylum]] in a [[European Union]] country.<ref>[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/article/1010/42/369633.htm Editor of News Portal Flees Country], ''[[The Moscow Times]]'', 7 August retrieved 31 August 2008</ref> Local police claimed that Yevloyev was shot after he had attempted to grab an [[assault rifle]] from one of the police officers in the car.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/01/world/europe/01ingushetia.html ''The New York Times'']</ref> Human rights groups have rejected this account of Yevloyev's death, and the United States [[State Department]] has called for an investigation of the killing and for those responsible to be "held to account for what happened".<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSN0244665820080902 ''Reuters'', "U.S. urges probe of journalist's death in Ingushetia", 2 Sep 2008]</ref> A spokesman for [[Vladimir Putin]] has said that an investigation will take place, but that Yevloyev had resisted arrest.<ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e4693d2c-791d-11dd-9d0c-000077b07658.html ''Financial Times'', "Tension in Ingushetia after journalist’s death", 3 September 2008]</ref>
In July 2008, [[Human Rights Watch]] documented dozens of arbitrary detentions, [[forced disappearance|disappearances]], acts of [[torture]], and extrajudicial executions in Ingushetia.<ref>[https://www.hrw.org/english/docs/2008/06/24/russia19194.htm Killings, Torture, Disappearances in Chechnya-Style Counterinsurgency], [[Human Rights Watch]], 31 August 2008</ref>
The [[Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] denounced Yevloyev's killing as an "assassination" aimed at cracking down on dissent in Ingushetia. The killing also triggered calls for Ingushetia's independence from Russia. The organizer of the protest rally, Magomed Khazibiyev, declared that the Ingush opposition would demand independence, appealing to [[International recognition of Abkhazia and South Ossetia|Russia's recognition]] of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]'s breakaway [[Abkhazia]] and [[South Ossetia]] as precedent.<ref>Catherine Belton, [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e4693d2c-791d-11dd-9d0c-000077b07658.html Tension in Ingushetia after journalist’s death]. ''[[The Financial Times]]''. 3 September 2008.</ref>
The funeral of Yevloyev developed into an anti-government protest, in which, according to organizers, several thousands participated. Early on 2 September, police dispersed a sleeping crowd of around 50 men who remained in the main square in [[Nazran]], Ingushetia's capital city.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/homepageCrisis/idUSL224586._CH_.2400 Police break up protest in Russia's Ingushetia]. Reuters. 2 September 2008.</ref>
His death investigation case is classified as "Murder by negligence" according to the [[Criminal Code of Russia]]. Another criminal case for his illegal detention (according to the investigators, police did not have the right to arrest him when they did) was opened in February 2009,<ref name=secondcase>{{cite news|first=Musa|last=Muradov|title=Убийство Магомеда Евлоева вышло на должностной уровень |url=http://www.kommersant.ru/doc.aspx?docsid=1139375|publisher=[[Kommersant]]|date=17 March 2009|accessdate=18 March 2009}}</ref> but withdrawn in March 2009.<ref>[http://www.rferl.org/content/Ingushetia_Prosecutor_Reverses_Decision_To_Investigate_Journalists_Death/1513766.html Ingushetia Prosecutor Reverses Decision To Investigate Journalist's Death]. [[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]. 20 March 2009</ref>
==Court== On 11 December 2009, a court in Ingushetia found Ibragim Yevloyev guilty of unintentionally murdering Magomed Yevloyev. Ibragim Yevloyev was sentenced to two years of a "colony-settlement". In February 2010 his sentence was mitigated to two years of freedom restriction.<ref name=lenta2010>[http://lenta.ru/news/2010/03/02/change1/ Sentence of Murderer of Ingush Oppositioner Mitigated], Lenta.Ru, February 2010 (in Russian)</ref>
Relatives of Magomed Yevloyev do not trust the official version. In their view, the owner of [[Ingushetiya.Ru]] was murdered intentionally. The family addressed the European Court on Human Rights with a complaint.<ref name=lenta2010/>

{{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Maureen Kimenye | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1983}} | birth_place = [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | education ='''[[Moi University]]'''
{{small|([[Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery]])}}

{{small|([[Tuberculosis|Diploma in Tuberculosis Epidemiology and Control]])}}

{{small|([[Project management|Diploma in Project Management]])}}
'''[[University of Nicosia]]'''
{{small|([[Master of Business Administration]])}} | occupation = Medical Researcher & Medical Administrator | years_active = 2003 to present | nationality = Kenya | ethnicity = | citizenship = Kenya | residence = [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] | known_for = Medicine | networth = | home_town = | title = Head of the Kenya National Tuberculosis, Leprosy & Lung Disease Control Programme. | website = | honorific_prefix = | spouse = | |}} Dr '''Maureen Kamene Kimenye Mariita''', commonly known as '''Maureen Kimenye''', is a [[Kenya]]n [[physician]] and [[administrator|medical administrator]], who serves as the Head of the National Tuberculosis, Leprosy & Lung Disease Control Programme, in the [[Ministry of Health (Kenya)| Kenyan Ministry of Health]].{{cite web|access-date=4 November 2018 |url=https://cdn.nation.co.ke/pdfs/Top40under40Women2018.pdf | format=PDF |title=Top 40 Under 40 Women In Kenya, 2018 | date=September 2018 |author=Business Daily Staff | newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |location=Nairobi}} ==Background and education== She was born in Kenya, circa 1983. After attending local primary and secondary schools, she was admitted to [[Moi University|Moi University School of Medicine]], where she obtained her [[Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery]] degree. She studied at ''The Research Institute of Tuberculosis, Japan'', graduating with a [[Tuberculosis|Diploma in Tuberculosis Epidemiology and Control]]. She also holds a [[Project management| Diploma in Project Management]], obtained from the ''Kenya Institute of Management'', in Nairobi, Kenya. She then spent one year in a fellowship program, studying [[Multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis|multiple drug resistant strains of tuberculosis]] and [[HIV]]/[[AIDS]] in [[Lesotho]], [[Southern Africa]]. Her [[Master of Business Administration]] degree was awarded by the [[University of Nicosia]] in [[Cyprus]].{{cite web|access-date=4 November 2018 |url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/maureen-kamene-kimenye-mariita-a4701330/ |title=Maureen Kamene Kimenye Mariita, Head of the National Tuberculosis Leprosy & Lung Disease Control Programme of the Government of Kenya |publisher=[[Linkedin.com]] |date=4 November 2018 |first=Maureen |last=Kimenye}} ==Career== Dr Maureen Kimenye is a leading authority in the treatment and control of tuberculosis in Sub-Saharan Africa.{{cite web|url=https://citizentv.co.ke/news/kenya-world-tuberculosis-day-maureen-kamene-kimenye-who-194688/ |title=Kenya marks World TB |publisher=Citizens Television Kenya |date=24 March 2018 |author=Citizen Reporter |access-date=4 November 2018 |location=Nairobi}} She oversaw the development of a mobile computer application, '''Tibu''', which allows doctors to track records of over 550,000 tuberculosis patients in Kenya. She has helped [[Namibia]] and [[Ethiopia]] replicate the application. She has a passion for teaching and is responsible for the education of over 1,000 people about how to treat tuberculosis. Using teleconferencing, she helps experts teach classes on tuberculosis. Some callers join with 15 or 30 other individuals within the call. The application known as '''TB Echo''', can host as many as 4,500 callers, simultaneously. ==Other considerations== In September 2018, [[Business Daily Africa]], a Kenyan, [[English language]], daily newspaper, named Dr. Maureen Kimenye, among the "Top 40 Under 40 Women in Kenya in 2018". ==See also== * [[Borna Nyaoke-Anoke]] * [[Shitsama Nyamweya]] * [[Catherine Nyongesa]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.stoptb.org/news/frompartners/2017/fp17_012.asp One-on-One with Dr Kamene Kimenye - Mariita on Project ECHO in Kenya] {{DEFAULTSORT:Kimenye, Maureen}} [[Category:1983 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Kenyan people]] [[Category:Kenyan women]] [[Category:Kenyan physicians]] [[Category:Kenyan women physicians]] [[Category:Moi University alumni]] [[Category:University of Nicosia alumni]]

{{Redirect|Mousavi|the surname|Mousavi (surname)}} {{pp-semi-blp|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox Prime Minister |name = Mir-Hossein Mousavi |image = Zahra Rahnavard, Mir Hossein Mousavi and Hamed Saber (cropped).jpg |caption = Mousavi on 19 August 2009 |order1 = [[List of Prime Ministers of Iran|49th]] |office1 = Prime Minister of Iran |president1 = [[Ali Khamenei]] |term_start1 = 31 October 1981 |term_end1 = 14 August 1989 |predecessor1 = [[Mohammad-Reza Mahdavi Kani]] (Acting) |successor1 = ''Office abolished'' |office2 = [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] |primeminister2 = [[Mohammad-Javad Bahonar]]
[[Mohammad-Reza Mahdavi Kani]] (Acting) |term_start2 = 15 August 1981 |term_end2 = 15 December 1981 |predecessor2 = [[Mohammad-Ali Rajai]] (Acting) |successor2 = [[Ali Akbar Velayati]] |office3 = [[Mostazafan Foundation|Head of Mostazafan Foundation]] |appointer3 = [[Ruhollah Khomeini]] |term_start3 = 4 December 1981 |term_end3 = 6 September 1989 |predecessor3 = [[Mohammad-Ali Rajai]] |successor3 = [[Mohsen Rafighdoost]] |office4 = [[Advisor to the President of Iran|Senior Advisor to the President of Iran]]{{citation|date=1997|journal=[[MEED]]|publisher=Economic East Economic Digest Ltd|volume=41|issue=40–51|page=20|quote=Hossain Moussavi has been appointed as President Khatami's top adviser, it was announced on 12 October.|title=News}} |president4 = [[Mohammad Khatami]] |term_start4 = 12 October 1997 |term_end4 = 3 August 2005 |predecessor4 = |successor4 = [[Mojtaba Samareh Hashemi]] |birth_name = Mir-Hossein Mousavi Khameneh |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1942|3|2|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Khameneh]], [[Iran]] |relatives = [[Hossein Sharifzadegan]] {{small|(brother-in-law)}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/mobile/world-middle-east-12433758|work=BBC|title= Iran 'arrests activists' ahead of planned march|accessdate=6 April 2016|date=11 February 2011}} |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[The Green Path of Hope]] (2009–present) |otherparty = [[Islamic Republican Party]] (1979–1987)
[[Movement of Militant Muslims]] (1977–1979) |alma_mater = [[Shahid Beheshti University|National University of Tehran]] |occupation = Architect, educator |spouse = {{marriage|[[Zahra Rahnavard]]|1969}} |children = 3 |residence = [[Tehran]], Iran |awards = [[File:Independence Ribbon Bar (I.R.Iran).svg|30px]] [[Order of Independence (Iran)|Excellent Order of Independence]]{{cite news|url=http://www.tasnimnews.com/fa/news/1392/06/02/122731/%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%86-%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D8%AF%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AA%DB%8C-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B2%D9%87%D8%A7%DB%8C-%D9%BE%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D8%AA%D9%85%DB%8C-%D9%88-%D8%A7%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF%DB%8C-%D9%86%DA%98%D8%A7%D8%AF-%D8%A8%D9%87-%DA%86%D9%87-%DA%A9%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%B1%D8%B3%DB%8C%D8%AF-%D8%AC%D8%AF%D9%88%D9%84|work=[[Tasnim News Agency]]|script-title=fa:نشان‌های دولتی در روزهای پایانی خاتمی و احمدی‌نژاد به چه‌کسانی رسید؟ |trans-title=|language=Persian|date=24 August 2013|access-date=15 April 2016}} |signature = Mir-Hossein Mousavi signature.svg |signature_alt = Mir-Hossein Mousavi |website = [http://www.kaleme.org/ kaleme.org] }} '''[[Sayyid|Mir]]-Hossein Mousavi Khameneh''' ({{lang-fa|میرحسین موسوی خامنه|Mīr-Hoseyn Mūsavī Khāmené}}, {{IPA-fa|miːɾ hoˈsɛjn ɛ muːsæˈviː jɛ xɑːmɛˈnɛ|pron}}; born 2 March 1942) is an Iranian [[Iranian reform movement|reformist]] politician, artist and architect who served as the seventy-ninth and last [[Prime Minister of Iran]] from 1981 to 1989. He was a reformist candidate for the [[Iranian presidential election, 2009|2009 presidential election]] and eventually the leader of the opposition in the [[2009–2010 Iranian election protests|post-election unrest]]. Mousavi served as the president of the [[Iranian Academy of the Arts|Iranian Academy of Arts]] until 2009, when Conservative authorities removed him.{{cite web|title=ميرحسين موسوی از رياست فرهنگستان هنر برکنار شد|url=http://www.radiofarda.com/content/o2_iran_fires_opposition_leader/1911161.html|publisher=Radio Farda|accessdate=14 July 2011}} In the early years of the revolution, Mousavi was the editor-in-chief of ''[[Islamic Republican (newspaper)|Jomhouri-e Eslami]]'', the official newspaper of the [[Islamic Republican Party]], before being elevated to [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] and eventually the post of Prime Minister. He was the last Prime Minister in Iran prior to the 1989 [[Iranian constitutional referendum, 1989|constitutional changes]] which removed the post of prime minister; he then went into semi-retirement for the next 20 years. He remains a member of the [[Expediency Discernment Council]] and the [[High Council of Cultural Revolution]]. However, he has not participated in their meetings for years, which is interpreted by political analysts and commentators as a sign of his disapproval. For the 2009 Iranian Presidential election, Mousavi came out of semi-retirement and ran as one of two Reformist candidates against the administration of incumbent [[President of Iran]] [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]]. According to official results, he didn't win the election, and following alleged vote rigging and manipulation, his campaign sparked a long protest that eventually turned into a national and international movement against the Government and Supreme Leader [[Ali Khamenei]]. Despite the violent crackdown, he remains the leader of the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green Movement]] but his movements have remained severely restricted. He chose green as his campaign color, a color which is pervasive in Iran.{{cite news|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/jun/1119.html|title=Even Iran Can Change|date=6 November 2009 |publisher=Peyvand|accessdate=18 June 2009}} He is currently under [[house arrest]] along with his wife and [[Mehdi Karroubi]].[https://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE13/086/2011/en Iran: Further information: Opposition leaders arbitrarily held] [[Amnesty International]], 29 September 2011 ==Early life, education and career== Seyyed Mir-Hossein Mousavi was born on 2 March 1942 in [[Khameneh]], [[East Azerbaijan]], Iran. He is an ethnic [[Iranian Azerbaijanis|Azerbaijani]],{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/5514320/The-challenger-who-is-poised-to-seize-Irans-presidency.html|title=The challenger who is poised to seize Iran's presidency|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=12 June 2009}} Born in north-western Iran in 1941, Mr Mousavi is from the country's Azeri ethnic minority.The Rising Tide of Cultural Pluralism: The Nation-State at Bay?, Crawford Young, p. 127, 1993 whose family originated from [[Tabriz]]. His father, Mir-Ismail, was a tea merchant from Tabriz. Mousavi grew up in Khameneh, and moved to [[Tehran]] following his graduation from high school in 1958.[http://www.biography.com/articles/Mousavi-Hossein-460468?part=0 Mousavi, Hossein Biography] Mousavi is a relative of fellow Khameneh native [[Ali Khamenei]]: Mousavi's grandmother is Khamenei's paternal aunt.{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/the-rebirth-of-an-iranian-revolutionary/article1191461/|title=The rebirth of an Iranian revolutionary|work=The Globe and Mail|author=Patrick Martin|date=23 June 2009|accessdate=24 June 2006}}{{cite book|author=Abbas Milani|title=The Myth of the Great Satan: A New Look at America's Relations with Iran|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YTrRom48fhAC&pg=PA123|accessdate=1 August 2013|date=31 July 2010|publisher=Hoover Press|isbn=978-0-8179-1136-2|pages=121}} [[File:Mostafa Chamran and Mir-Hossein Mousavi.jpg|thumb|left|Mousavi with [[Mostafa Chamran]], 1970's]] He earned his undergraduate degree in architecture from the [[National University of Tehran]] (now Shahid Beheshti University), and in 1969 was awarded his master's degree in architecture from the National University of Tehran,{{cite web|url=http://siavashon.ir/nikaeen/1015.html |script-title=fa:میر حسین موسوی کیست؟ |date=18 October 2008 |publisher=Siavashon |language=Persian |accessdate=21 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129134100/http://siavashon.ir/nikaeen/1015.html |archivedate=29 January 2009 |df= }} focusing primarily on traditional [[Iranian architecture]]. While a student, he was an active member of the leftist [[Anjoman-e-Eslami|Islamic association of students]]. During his college years, Mousavi had a close relationship with the [[Freedom Movement of Iran]], a religious-nationalist political party founded by [[Ali Shariati]], whom Mousavi admired for many years. Although the party would not be invited to the post-[[1979 Iranian Revolution|revolution]] government, many future political leaders of Iran who were affiliated with the party at the time, among them [[Mehdi Bazargan]], [[Yadolah Sahabi]], [[Mahmoud Taleghani]], and [[Mostafa Chamran]] would become Mousavi's closest allies. Mousavi was among the student activists who regularly attended Ali Shariati's lectures at [[Hosseiniyeh Ershad]] of Tehran, where Mousavi also exhibited his artwork under the pseudonym Hossein Rah'jo.{{cite web|last=Alavi |first=Nasrin |title=Iran: a blind leap of faith |url=http://www.opendemocracy.net/article/iran-a-blind-leap-of-faith |publisher=Open Democracy |date=2 June 2009 |accessdate=14 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701000257/http://www.opendemocracy.net/article/iran-a-blind-leap-of-faith |archivedate=1 July 2011 |df= }} In 1969, Mousavi married [[Zahra Rahnavard]], a fellow university student who specialized in sculpture, and was among the well-known students of Ali Shariati.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2009/05/090521_og_ir88_mosavi.shtml|script-title=fa:زندگی‌نامه نامزدها: میر حسین موسوی|date=21 May 2009|work=BBC Persian|language=Persian|accessdate=21 June 2009}} Rahnavard later became the [[Chancellor]] of [[Alzahra University]] as well as political adviser to Iran's former President [[Mohammad Khatami]].{{cite web|url=http://zeldalily.com/index.php/2009/05/a-first-lady-for-iran/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715094926/http://zeldalily.com/index.php/2009/05/a-first-lady-for-iran/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 July 2009 |title=A First Lady for Iran |publisher=Zeldaily |accessdate=21 June 2009 }} The couple have three daughters; all speak [[Azerbaijani language|Azeri]], [[Persian Language|Persian]], English, and [[Arabic]]. ==Iranian Revolution== Mousavi and his wife had an active role in the success of the [[Iranian revolution]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8103851.stm|title=Profile: Mir Hossein Mousavi|date=16 June 2009|publisher=BBC|accessdate=21 June 2009}} He was imprisoned for organizing street protests against the [[constitutional monarchy|monarchy]] of [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi]]. As the [[Iranian revolution]] neared, Mousavi, whose earliest political hero was [[Che Guevara]],[http://tpmcafe.talkingpointsmemo.com/2009/06/17/different_this_time/ Different This Time] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620000624/http://tpmcafe.talkingpointsmemo.com/2009/06/17/different_this_time/ |date=20 June 2009 }} by Jon Taplin, ''Talking Points Memo'', 17 June 2009 became more actively involved in the struggle. He initially participated in the establishment of the Jonbesh-e Mosalmanan-e Mobarez ([[Movement of Militant Muslims]]) alongside [[Habibollah Peyman]] which eventually led him to join ranks with [[Mohammad Beheshti]], who was a close associate of the revolution leader, [[Ruhollah Khomeini]], and abandoned his previous connections with Ali Shariati. [[File:People of second cabinet of I.R.Iran.jpg|thumb|Mousavi (first from right, sitting) as Minister of Foreign Affairs in the cabinet of President [[Mohammad-Ali Rajai]] and Prime Minister [[Mohammad Javad Bahonar]], 1981]] Following the collapse of the Shah's regime in 1979, Mousavi helped [[Mohammad Beheshti]] found the Islamic Republican Party in 1979 in order to assist the establishment of the [[Islamic Republic]] in Iran and hasten the overthrow of Iran's monarchy. He became the political secretary of the party, and chief editor of ''Jomhouri-e Eslami'', the party's official newspaper. For this, he is widely viewed as "The Architect" of the Islamic Republic both in Iran and abroad. In mid-1979, he was appointed by Khomeini to the [[Iranian Council of Islamic revolution]].Brownlee (2007), p.103 As the chief editor of ''Jomhouri-e Eslami'', he was a loud critic and opponent of [[Abolhassan Banisadr]], the first president of the Islamic Republic, until the latter's 1981 flight to France, following a successful impeachment by parliament.Baktiari (1996), pp.80–1. During Banisadr's presidency, the prime minister [[Mohammad Ali Rajai]] nominated Mousavi as his foreign minister, however Banisadr opposed the nomination and Mousavi was not appointed.{{cite web|last=Amouee |first=Bahman Ahmadi |title=میرحسین موسوی، اندیشه های اقتصادی تا احساسات شاعرانه |url=http://www.amouee.net/spip.php?article322 |date=26 April 2009 |accessdate=21 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113113529/http://www.amouee.net/spip.php?article322 |archivedate=13 November 2011 |df= }} On 15 August 1981, as part of the restructuring of the government in Rajai's cabinet, Mousavi was appointed [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|foreign minister]]. He held the post until 15 December 1981, when he received the higher appointment of prime minister. ==Prime ministership== {{See also|Prime ministership of Mir-Hossein Mousavi}} [[File:Ali Khamenei (Left) - Mir-Hossein Mousavi (Right).jpg|thumb|left|Mousavi (right) with then-President [[Ali Khamenei]] (left)]] In August 1981, President [[Mohammad-Ali Rajai]] and Prime Minister [[Mohammad-Javad Bahonar]] were assassinated in an explosion. [[Ali Khamenei]] was then elected as the third [[president of Iran]] in the [[Iranian presidential election, October 1981]]. He put forward [[Ali Akbar Velayati]] as his prime minister, but the Iranian parliament did not give him the [[vote of confidence]], and he was defeated with a vote of 80 to 74. Although Khamenei had strong reservations with Mousavi, as a compromise with the left-leaning parliament, agreed to offer Mousavi for the post of premier. On 28 October 1981, with the approval of Khomeini, the parliament approved Mousavi with a vote of 115 to 39 to become the 79th [[prime minister of Iran]] on 31 October 1981.{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20090609/155210271.html|title=Biography: Mir-Hossein Mousavi|date=2009-06-09|agency=RIA Novosti|accessdate=21 June 2009}}''Iran under the Ayatollahs'', by Dilip Hiro, p. 198 The conflicts between Mousavi, who belonged to the left wing of the Islamic Republic, with Ali Khamenei (the current [[Supreme Leader of Iran|leader of Iran]]), who belonged to the right wing of the Islamic Republic, continued during their eight years of shared governance. However, an escalation in conflicts between the two led to Mousavi's resignation shortly after the end of the [[Iran–Iraq War]] in 1988. As the prime minister, Mousavi had the full backing of Ruhollah Khomeini, the supreme leader, and he refused to accept his resignation. While his government was viewed as somewhat liberal, he was still under the pressure of hardliners, though Khomeini generally protected Mousavi from the conservatives and gave him a free rein in deciding actions for the economy. However, his involvement in security matters remained less clear, and it was disputed whether or not Mousavi was involved in the killing of thousands of dissidents and minorities in Kurdistan and Mazandaran during this time. It has generally been accepted that Mousavi and Mohsen Rezaee (who was in charge of the Revolutionary Guards during this time) have never been close, though he was in charge of foreign operations, particularly in Lebanon. [[File:عباس میرزا ابوطالبی به همراه مهندس میر حسین موسوی.jpg|thumb|Mousavi and Abbas Mirza Abutalebi during the [[Iran–Iraq War]]]] [[File:Mousavi - khatami 1985.jpg|thumb|left|Mousavi with [[Mohammad Khatami]], then Culture Minister, and the next [[President of Iran|President]] in 1985]] Mousavi's premiership coincided with the Iran–Iraq War. He guided the country through its war with Iraq, and earned popular acclaim for his stewardship of the national economy. He pioneered a [[voucher|bond]]-based economy, which many believe was responsible for a fair distribution of goods among the people throughout the Iran–Iraq War.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7e0997f4-e40f-11dd-8274-0000779fd2ac.html?nclick_check=1|title=Iran's ex-PM seen as candidate|date=16 January 2009|work=[[Financial Times]]}} Many analysts praise his handling of [[economy of Iran|Iran's economy]], his civil and economic leadership during the Iran–Iraq War, and his efforts to end Iran's international isolation.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/persian/iran/2009/03/090303_mg_mir_hossain_mosavi.shtml|date=3 March 2009|publisher=BBC|language=Persian|title=Mir-Hossein: Attempt to Exit 20-year long Isolation? (میر حسین موسوی؛ تلاش برای خروج از انزوای ۲۰ ساله؟),}} Others remember him as being "unpredictable" and less able to navigate Iran's labyrinthine political system than were his rivals.{{cite news|first=Borzou|last=Daragah|author2=Ramin Mostaghim |author3=Kim Murphy |title=Mir-Hossein Mousavi's unusual career arc|date=22 June 2009|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-iran-mousavi22-2009jun22,0,7316075.story|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=22 June 2009}} In 1986, Mousavi played a great role in the [[Iran–Contra affair]] and secret negotiations and dealing with USA on helping them free the American hostages in Lebanon, in return for sale of the American weapons and spare-parts that Iran's army badly needed for the Iran–Iraq War. A year after the end of the [[Iran–Iraq War]] on 20 August 1988, Ruhollah Khomeini died (June 3, 1989), and Ali Khamenei was elected as the new [[Supreme Leader]] by the [[Assembly of Experts]]. Following his death, Mousavi and his fellow left-wingers lost their main source of support within the establishment. During the parliament hearing on post-war reconstruction plans, Mousavi had heated arguments with [[Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]], the speaker of [[Iran's parliament]] at the time, over Rafsanjani's suggestion that Iran accept the offer of western countries to help with post-war reconstruction. On 28 July 1989, the [[Constitution of Islamic Republic of Iran|constitution]] was amended and approved by Iranian voters in a [[Iranian constitutional referendum, 1989|national referendum]] with a 97% yes vote. At this time, [[Mehdi Karrubi]] had been elected as the new speaker of the parliament, to whom the amended constitution was declared.{{cite web|url=http://www2.irna.ir/occasion/12azar84/indexghanon.htm |script-title=fa:تصویب قانون اساسی جمهوری اسلامی |publisher=[[IRNA]] news agency |language=Persian |accessdate=21 June 2009 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414231346/http://www2.irna.ir/occasion/12azar84/indexghanon.htm |archivedate=14 April 2009 |df= }} One of these amendments abolished the position of Prime Minister. Rafsanjani was [[Iranian presidential election, 1989|elected]] as the fourth president of Iran on 28 July 1989, and became the president on 3 August 1989. Mousavi's premiership ended on the same date. Mousavi was not invited to be a participant in the new government headed by Rafsanjani, and disappeared from the public sphere. ==Retirement from politics== [[File:آرامگاه شهدای هفتم تیر در بهشت زهرای تهران 07.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Hafte Tir bombing]] victims' mausoleum, which is designed by Mousavi]] When Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic Republic, died in 1989, Mousavi was no longer welcome in the government. It was the start of 20 years of an almost total absence from public life for Mousavi, which many considered as a sign of his disapproval of the established government, though he did sit on two high-level government councils. In 1989, Ali Khamenei named him as a member of the [[Expediency Discernment Council]], his membership of which still continues. Mousavi has been a member of the [[Supreme Council of Cultural Revolution]] since 1996. He was also the political adviser of president [[Hashemi Rafsanjani]] (1989–1997) and senior adviser of president Khatami (1997–2005). During these years, he partly retired from politics and returned to architecture and teaching, becoming President of the [[Iranian Academy of Arts]], one of the four academies of the Islamic Republic of Iran. The main building of the Academy is designed by him.{{cite web|title=آفتاب – افتتاح ساختمان اصلی|url=http://www.aftabnews.ir/vdcjtyeo.uqeovzsffu.html|publisher=Aftab News|accessdate=14 July 2011}} At the same time, he developed his passion for painting and writing poetry. He was a professor at [[Shahid Beheshti University]] and later joined the Academic staff of [[Tarbiat Modares University]]. His main field is architecture, and buildings such as ''Kanoon-e Tohid'' in Tehran, ''Beynolharamein Bazaar'' in [[Shiraz]], ''Haft-e-tir Martyr's tomb'' in [[Behesht-e Zahra|Tehran's Behesht-e Zahra]], and ''Salman mosque'' in the presidential residence are examples of his work. In recent years, he has been more active in painting and has participated in many exhibitions. == Presidential candidacy== {{Main article|Mir-Hossein Mousavi presidential campaign, 2009}} ===Pre-2009=== Mousavi refused to run for the presidency in the 1997 elections, which caused the reformists to turn to his former Cabinet Minister, then a little-known cleric, [[Mohammad Khatami]], who was elected by a landslide. During Khatami's administration, Mousavi served as the Senior Adviser to the President. Mousavi was considered the leading candidate from the reformist alliance to run in the [[Iranian presidential election, 2005]]. However, on 12 October 2004, he officially declined the proposal after a meeting with President Mohammad Khatami and the two other top members of one of Iran's main Reformist parties, the [[Association of Combatant Clerics]], [[Mehdi Karroubi]] and [[Mohammad Mousavi-Khoiniha]]. ===2009 presidential candidacy=== [[File:Iran election (2).jpg|thumb|left|Mousavi supporters in Tehran]] After 20 years of political silence, on 9 March 2009, Mousavi announced his intention to run in the [[Iranian presidential election, 2009|2009 Iranian presidential election]]. He stated that his main goals were: to institutionalize social justice, equality and fairness, freedom of expression, to root out corruption and to speed up Iran's stagnant process of privatization, and thus move Iran away from what he called "an alms-based economy".{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.com/election2009/detail.aspx?id=88106 |title=Moussavi officially joins presidential fray |publisher=[[PressTV]] |date=10 March 2009 |accessdate=13 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618050730/http://www.presstv.com/election2009/detail.aspx?id=88106 |archivedate=18 June 2009 |df= }} Mousavi criticized the then-current conservative President, [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]], for his alleged economic mismanagement, asking, when Iran "was making profits from the high prices of oil, did he (Ahmadinejad) envisage a situation when the prices would fall?" On 16 March 2009, the former Iranian President Khatami withdrew from the election in support of Mir-Hossein Mousavi.{{cite web|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/09/mar/1195.html|title= Khatami will soon withdraw candidacy in favor of Mousavi: source |publisher=payvand|date=15 March 2009|accessdate=13 April 2009}} ====Platform==== Mousavi ran as an independent Principled Reformist candidate.http://www5.irna.ir/View/FullStory/?NewsId=392200{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Although he is one of the original founders of the Iranian reformist camp, he shares many principles of the conservatives. Many reformist parties, among them reformist Islamic Iranian Participation Front, whose main candidate was Khatami, have supported his candidacy after the latter withdrew from the race.{{cite web|url=http://norooznews.ir/news/11287.php |title=:: پايگاه اطلاع رساني نوروز بيانيه جبهه مشاركت در حمايت از مهندس مير حسين موسوي در انتخابات دهمين دوره رياست جمهوري |publisher=Norooz News |accessdate=9 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107020846/http://norooznews.ir/news/11287.php |archivedate=7 January 2010 }} Many supporters of the reformist movement, however, objected to Mousavi's candidacy on the grounds that he was not committed to the principles of the reformist parties.{{cite web|url=http://www.mowj.ir/|title=موج سوم؛ پایگاه اطلاع رسانی "پویش (کمپین) دعوت از خاتمی"|publisher=Mowj|accessdate=9 August 2010}} Although Mousavi stated that he was not running as a reformist, he indicated that he welcomed the support of different parties, both reformist and conservative.{{cite web|url=http://www2.irna.ir/fa/news/view/line-7/8802189812170714.htm |title=IRNA |publisher=.irna |accessdate=9 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217191610/http://www2.irna.ir/fa/news/view/line-7/8802189812170714.htm |archivedate=17 February 2012 |df= }} He started his campaign from the center of Iranian politics; over time, he shifted more towards the left by declaring his support for reforms. Although some active members of the conservative camp, such as [[Emad Afroogh]], as well as the conservative newspaper ''Jomhouri-e Eslami'', supported Mousavi's candidacy, he did not receive the official backing of any major conservative party. His candidacy made it harder for the conservatives to support [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]], and large conservative parties, such as the Combatant Clergy Association, did not back the current President for a second term of office.{{cite web|url=http://www.roozonline.com/persian/news/newsitem/article/2009/may/18//-8a5153f5c7.html|title=جامعه روحانیت دو پاره شد|publisher=rooz online|date=22 March 2010|accessdate=9 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090522182832/http://www.roozonline.com/persian/news/newsitem/article/2009/may/18/-8a5153f5c7.html|archivedate=22 May 2009|df=dmy-all}} ====Domestic policies==== [[File:Mir Hossein Mousavi in Zanjan by Mardetanha 0904.jpg|thumb|Mousavi speaking in [[Zanjan, Iran|Zanjan]] during presidential campaign]] Mousavi had on numerous occasions indicated his wish to change the constitution in order to remove the existing ban on the private ownership of television stations (currently all Iranian television stations are state-owned), as well as transfer the control of the law-enforcement forces to the President (so that they represent the people, since the people directly elect the President through popular vote) from the Supreme Leader.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.com/election2009/detail.aspx?id=90057 |title=Mousavi backs private TV, urges change recognition |publisher=[[PressTV]] |date=31 March 2009 |accessdate=13 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618053241/http://www.presstv.com/election2009/detail.aspx?id=90057 |archivedate=18 June 2009 |df= }} He said that "the issue of non-compliance with the Iranian rules and regulations is the biggest problem that the country is currently faced with" and that he wished to put in place ways to enforce the laws further,{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.com/election2009/detail.aspx?id=90375 |title=Moussavi warns against governmental cover-up |publisher=[[PressTV]] |date=3 April 2009 |accessdate=13 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618053316/http://www.presstv.com/election2009/detail.aspx?id=90375 |archivedate=18 June 2009 |df= }} and that it was also important to bring an end to keeping the populace uninformed about government matters. Among his policies were creation of a free environment for the flow of information and corrections to the national budget.{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,622225,00.html |title=The Answer To Ahmadinejad |work=Der Spiegel |date= 27 April 2009 }} He wanted to promote the creation of private, non-governmental TV networks{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=90056§ionid=351020101 |publisher=[[PressTV]] |date=31 March 2009 |title=Mousavi backs private TV, urges change recognition |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715073643/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=90056§ionid=351020101 |archivedate=15 July 2009 |df= }} and stop the operation of the "[[Guidance Patrol|Moral Police]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=90979§ionid=351020101 |title=Mousavi: Moral police, provincial visits irrelevant |publisher=[[PressTV]] |date=9 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619225512/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=90979§ionid=351020101 |archivedate=19 June 2009 |df= }} He has spoken about his opposition to massive changes in ministries, which he claims is what [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad|Ahmadinejad]] has done. The [[BBC]] reported that Mousavi "called for greater personal freedoms in Iran and criticized the ban on private television channels", but "refused to back down from [[nuclear programme of Iran|the country's disputed nuclear programme]], saying it was "for peaceful purposes".[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8060304.stm#mousavi "Iran's presidential candidates"], BBC, 21 May 2009 Regarding the Iranian nuclear program, his plan includes a reduction of the cost by opposing radical approaches while maintaining what he sees as "Iran's right to civilian nuclear technology".{{cite web |url=http://origin2.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,512770,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090612193156/http://origin2.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,512770,00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 June 2009 |title=Iran's Reform Candidate, Mir Hossein Mousavi, Says Open to U.S. Negotiations |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=6 April 2009 }} Mousavi has stated that giving up the country's nuclear program would be "irreparable" and that the Iranian people support the nuclear program. "No one in Iran will accept suspension," Mousavi has said, adding that if elected, his policy would be to work to provide "guarantees" that Tehran's nuclear activities would never divert to non-peaceful aims.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=91361§ionid=351020101 |title=Mousavi: Iran will never halt enrichment |date=14 April 2009 |publisher=Press TV |accessdate=1 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417033036/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=91361§ionid=351020101 |archivedate=17 April 2009 |df= }} On 30 May, Mousavi pledged that if elected he would amend "[[women's rights in Iran|discriminatory and unjust regulations]]" against women, and take other measures in favour of women's rights and equality. He said that he would seek to disband the so-called morality police force, and ensure that Iranian women are treated equally, with the ability to attain financial empowerment and to serve at the highest levels of decision making bodies.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8075603.stm|title=Iran candidate Mousavi backs women's rights |publisher=BBC News|date=30 May 2009}} ====Foreign policies==== Mousavi directly addressed activating foreign policy to boost national interest by reducing tensions with other nations. This included negotiating with U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] if "his actions are in keeping with his words". He condemned Ahmadinejad's attitude toward [[The Holocaust]] (namely, that it was "a myth"), and condemned the killing of Jews in the Holocaust. ==Protests to the election results== {{main article|2009 Iranian election protests}} The election was held on 12 June 2009. The official results showed Ahmadinejad winning by a landslide, though Mousavi and many others believed the results to be fraudulent, suggesting that the Interior Minister, [[Sadegh Mahsouli]], an ally of Ahmadinejad, interfered with the election and distorted the votes to keep Ahmadinejad in power.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/12/AR2009061200916_2.html|title=Iran Election In Dispute as 2 Candidates Claim Victory|work=The Washington Post|date=13 June 2009|first=Thomas|last=Erdbrink|accessdate=5 April 2010}} Mousavi has claimed victory, and called for his supporters to celebrate it, sparking [[2009 Iranian election protests|large protests]] as a result.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/06/14/iran.protests.twitter/index.html |title=Tear gas and Twitter: Iranians take their protests online |publisher=CNN |date=15 June 2009}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/blog/2009/jul/29/iran-election-protest-dead-missing |title=Iran election protests: the dead, jailed and missing |work=The Guardian |location=UK |date=29 July 2009 |accessdate=19 December 2009 |first=Simon |last=Jeffery}} {{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/12/07/iran.protest.warnings/index.html#cnnSTCText |title=Iran police clash with protesters |publisher=CNN |date=7 December 2009}} {{quote|"Previously, he was revolutionary, because everyone inside the system was a revolutionary. But now he's a reformer. Now he knows Gandhi – before he knew only Che Guevara. If we gain power through aggression we would have to keep it through aggression. That is why we're having a green revolution, defined by peace and democracy."| [[Mohsen Makhmalbaf]], Mousavi's spokesman, 19 June 2009[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/jun/19/iran-election-mousavi-ahmadinejad I speak for Mousavi. And Iran] by Mohsen Makhmalbaf, ''The Guardian'', 19 June 2009}} Due to protests, from the opposition, the Supreme Leader ordered a partial recount of the election results. The recount was a random counting of 10% of the ballots. In order to create transparency, a 12-member council showed the recount on television, and concluded that President Ahmadinejad still led Mousavi after the recount. After the recount, the Guardian council certified the election, and concluded no evidence of irregularities, and closed the dossier on the election.{{cite news|agency=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/vcCandidateFeed1/idUSLT437642|accessdate=14 June 2009|title=Iran upholds Ahmadinejad victory, says matter closed|date=29 June 2009}} ===Beginning of the Green Movement=== [[File:6th Day - Mousavi inside the Crowd.jpg|thumb|left|upright|250px|Mousavi at the protests of 2009]] The Iranian Green Movement refers to a series of actions after the Iranian presidential election, 2009, in which protesters demanded the removal of Mahmoud Ahmadinejad from office. [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]], [[Mehdi Karroubi]], [[Hossein-Ali Montazeri]] and Mohammad Khatami are recognized as leaders of the Green Movement.{{cite web|url=http://asemandailynews.com/?p=2417| script-title=fa:دعوتنامه برگزارکنندگان مراسم ۱۸ تیر از موسوی و مهدی کروبی و محمد خاتمی|accessdate=5 July 2009|date=5 July 2009|work=Aseman Daily News|language=Persian}} Where is my vote? ({{lang-fa|رای من کجاست؟}}) was a motto used during the protests. Anti-Ahmadinejad protesters chanted the English-language phrase in numbers not seen since the 1979 [[Iranian Revolution]], in an attempt to receive international attention. The Iranian Government had released results claiming a two-thirds majority for Ahmadinejad, but supporters of Mousavi and [[Karroubi]], the moderate opposition leaders, accused the government of [[vote rigging|rigging the vote]]. In the aftermath of the election and ensuing comments by Ahmadinejad and other conservative leaders, calling the opposition "a pile of dust" (خس و خاشاک), protests were widened and massive peaceful protests were held around the country. Although the Iranian government prohibited any gatherings of protesters in Tehran and across the country, significantly slowed down internet access and censored any form of media supporting the opposition, hundreds of thousands of Iranians marched in defiance.[http://www.miamiherald.com/news/world/AP/story/1098601.html Iranians, by hundreds of thousands, ask: Where is my vote?] ''Miami Herald''. Large numbers of protesters were arrested, and several were killed by the police and militia forces [[Basij]]. [[Death of Neda Agha-Soltan|Neda Agha-soltan]] and [[Sohrab Aarabi]] were among the victims, and alleged cases of rape in prison ([[Taraneh Mousavi]]) were also uncovered. Since the election, the government has severely restricted the access of foreign and Iranian media to footage and information relating to opposition activities. As a result, scenes of the massive street protests and more frequent student protests have been filmed by participants themselves. ===Death of Mousavi's nephew=== Seyed Ali Mousavi was the nephew of Mousavi.[http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/meast/12/27/iran.protests/index.html Several killed, 300 arrested in Tehran protests] ''CNN'', 28 December 2009 Ali Mousavi died on 27 December 2009, during the [[2009 Iranian election protests]], when he was reportedly shot in either the back or the chest by security forces during demonstrations against [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]]'s contested election win.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/middle_east/article6969523.ece Hardliners seize Mousavi corpse as Iran regime hits back], ''The Times'', 29 December 2009 Iranian filmmaker Mohsen Makhmalbaf, the official spokesman of Mir-Hossein Moussavi's campaign abroad, told BBC News in an interview that Iranian secret police had called Seyed Ali Mousavi several times, days before he was shot, saying: "We will kill you."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8433991.stm Iran reformist Mousavi's nephew 'got death threats'], ''BBC'', 29 December 2009 After he died, his body was taken to Ebn-e Sina hospital, where protesters demonstrated outside. The protesters were broken up with tear gas by the Iranian security forces. It was later revealed that the government had removed his body and taken it to an undisclosed location in an attempt to crack down on the protests.[http://www.sanfranciscosentinel.com/?p=54286 Seven Iranian Opposition Leaders Arrested – Seyed Ali Mousavi's Body Goes Missing], ''San Francisco Sentinel'', 28 December 2009 ===The Green Path of Hope=== Mousavi and other reformist leaders are now working with peaceful and legal methods to widen the influence of their reforms. They have set up a new coalition, named The Green Path of Hope. Iranian political parties and movements need to be authorized by the [[Ministry of Interior (Iran)|Interior Ministry]]. Mousavi neither recognizes the current government as legitimate, nor is likely to receive permission; the movement was named a "path" in order bypass this law.{{cite web|author=Copyright: gooya.com 2010 |url=http://news.gooya.com/politics/archives/2009/08/092369.php |title=gooya news:: politics: جزييات "راه سبز اميد" از زبان عليرضا بهشتی: خاتمی و کروبی عضو شورای مرکزی هستند، کميته‌های "راه سبز اميد" در حال شکل گيری است، ايلنا |publisher=News.gooya.com |accessdate=9 August 2010}} The Green Path of Hope seeks to continue protests against Ahmadinejad's presidency following lawful and peaceful methods, and the full execution of the constitution, as Mousavi says:{{cite web|url=http://www.parlemannews.ir/index.aspx?n=2694 |title=پارلمان نیوز : تشکیلات "راه سبز امید" را ایجاد می‌کنیم تا حقوق مردم را استیفا کنیم/با برخوردهای اخیر، جا دارد انسان سر به زیر خاک کند |publisher=Parlemannews.ir |accessdate=9 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100720180530/http://www.parlemannews.ir/index.aspx?n=2694 |archivedate=20 July 2010 |df= }} {{quote |text=You can't follow some parts of the constitution and throw the rest into a bin.}} Mousavi is quoted in describing the movement:[http://www.upi.com/Top_News/2009/08/16/Mousavi-announces-new-political-party/UPI-34501250401917/ Mousavi announces new political party], [[United Press International]], 16 August 2009 {{quote |text=The Green Path of Hope is formed for the sake of people’s rightful demands and for claiming their rights... the color green is the symbol of this movement; its slogan is demanding the impeccable implementation of the constitution, and innumerable self-motivated independent societies form the body of this movement.}} According to organization officials, the movement encompasses numerous political parties, NGOs and social networks. Mousavi emphasized that existent, autonomous social networks in the community are part of this movement:{{cite news|url=http://www.ilna.ir/fullStory.aspx?ID=71086 |title=Green path of hope, Mousavi's new organization |accessdate=18 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723080421/http://www.ilna.ir/fullStory.aspx?ID=71086 |archivedate=23 July 2010 |df= }} {{quote |text=During the election, our mottos supported and remained in the framework of the constitution; today we are devoted to those slogans. We believe that if the people's demands were treated fairly, instead of being distorted by the media and linked to foreigners, and the government promoted truth by fair criticism, our mottos could satisfy the public.}} The "Green Path" has six main members on its central council, who are connected to reformist parties, NGOs, and social networks. The main body will be ordinary protesters. The strategy is to connect existent pressures and issues in society in a social network, and to therefore lead protests in a lawful manner. ===Arab Spring=== {{main article|Arab Spring}} In the wake of the [[Tunisian revolution|Tunisian]] and [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|Egyptian]] revolutions, Green movement leaders in Iran called for demonstrations on 14 February 2011. The government responded by placing leaders of the movement under house arrest, and on 14 February Iranian state TV broadcast images of "some 50 conservative MPs marching through parliament's main hall" chanting "Death to Mousavi, death to Karroubi".[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12462491 Iran unrest: MPs call for death of Mousavi and Karroubi], BBC News, 15 February 2011 ===House arrest=== Mousavi and his wife, as well as Mehdi Karoubi, another opposition figure, were put under [[house arrest]] after they urged their supporters to organize demonstrations in support of uprisings in the Arab world in February 2011.{{cite news|title=Iranian Authorities Arrest Opposition Leader’s Daughters |url=http://updatednews.ca/2013/02/11/iranian-authorities-arrest-opposition-leaders-daughters/ |accessdate=11 February 2013 |newspaper=Updated News |date=11 February 2013 |agency=Reuters |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130708095457/http://updatednews.ca/2013/02/11/iranian-authorities-arrest-opposition-leaders-daughters/ |archivedate=8 July 2013 |df= }} On 2 February 2013, Iran's security forces arrested Mousavi's two daughters, Zahra and Nargess Mousavi, in their home.{{cite news|title=Daughters of Iranian Opposition Leaders Arrested|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/13/feb/1093.html|accessdate=11 February 2013|newspaper=Payvand|date=11 February 2013|agency=Radio Zamaneh}} The semi-official news agency ILNA reported that they were questioned, and then freed the same day.{{cite news|title=Iran releases daughters of opposition leader |url=https://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/iran-releases-daughters-opposition-leader |accessdate=2 September 2017 |work=CNSNews.com |agency=Associated Press |date=11 February 2013 }} After the election of [[Hassan Rouhani]] as [[Iranian presidential election, 2013|President]] in 2013, it was announced that Mousavi and Rahnavard would soon be freed from house arrest. However, this had not occurred as of 2018.{{cite news|last1=Blair|first1=David|title=Hassan Rouhani's glaring failure to curb human rights abuses in Iran|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/11631210/Hassan-Rouhanis-glaring-failure-to-curb-human-rights-abuses-in-Iran.html|accessdate=12 June 2015|agency=The Telegraph}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Muhannad
مهند | image= Muhannad.jpg | imagesize=200px | birth_date = 1969{{cite web|url=http://www.kavkaz-uzel.ru/articles/184167/ |title=НАК: один из убитых в Чечне боевиков является эмиссаром 'Аль-Каиды' на Северном Кавказе |publisher=Кавказский Узел |date=22 March 2011 |accessdate=23 April 2011 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yAfn2lAS |archivedate=April 24, 2011 }} | birth_place = | death_place = | death_date = 21 April 2011{{cite web|url=http://rt.com/news/al-qaeda-commander-killed-chechnya/ |title=Al-Qaeda terrorist commander killed in Chechnya |publisher=Russia Today |date=22 April 2011 |accessdate=26 April 2011 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zelKVuDn |archivedate=June 23, 2011 }} | religion = [[Sunni Islam]] | office1 = [[Arab Mujahideen in Chechnya|4th Emir of the Arab Mujahideen in Chechnya]] | term_start1 = 9 December 2006 | term_end1 = 21 April 2011 | predecessor1 = [[Abu Hafs al-Urduni]] | successor1 = [[Abdulla Kurd]] | Infobox Military Person | allegiance = [[Caucasus Emirate]] | Active = 1980's-2004 | commands = [[Arab Mujahideen in Chechnya]] | battles = [[Second Chechen War]]
[[Insurgency in the North Caucasus|North Caucasus Insurgency]] }} '''Melfi Al Hussaini Al Harbi''', more commonly known as '''Muhannad''' ('''مهند'''; Mukhannad or Mukhanad, {{lang-ru|Муханнад, sometimes Моганнед or Моханнад}}), and also known as '''Abu Anas''' ('''ابو أنس'''), was a [[Mujahideen|Mujahid]] [[Emir]] (commander) fighting in [[Second Chechen War|Chechnya]]. Following the death of [[Abu Hafs al-Urduni]] on 26 November 2006, he was named leader of the [[Arab Mujahideen in Chechnya]],{{cite web|url=http://www.kavkazcenter.com/eng/content/2006/12/12/6803.shtml |title=Commander Muhannad Assumes Leadership of the Arab Mujahideen in Chechnya |publisher=Kavkaz Center |date=12 December 2006 |accessdate=23 April 2011 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zel3sumW |archivedate=June 23, 2011 }} the battalion of foreign fighters once commanded by the notorious Saudi-born [[Ibn al-Khattab]]. Although Russian intelligence has claimed that he was a native of Jordan who served as a combat pilot (achieving the rank of Lieutenant) in the Jordanian Air Force and who also underwent military training in the United States they are not considered true. He is not Jordanian,{{cite web|url=http://www.kavkaz-uzel.ru/articles/184324/ |title=Убитого в Чечне ‘Моханнада’ выдали свои, утверждают силовики |publisher=Кавказский Узил |date=25 March 2011 |accessdate=24 June 2011 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zgXkSGkm |archivedate=June 24, 2011 }} it is reported in other sources that he was Saudi.{{cite web|url= https://www.webcitation.org/5zek4KcL0 |title=Emir Muhannad: The Last of Chechnya’s Arab Volunteers |publisher=The Jamestown Foundation |date=29 April 2011 |accessdate=22 June 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/legendary_arab_commander_reported_killed_in_chechnya/9502477.html |title=Legendary Arab Commander Reported Killed in Chechnya |publisher=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty |date=22 April 2011 |accessdate=23 April 2011 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5zekM6zYr |archivedate=June 23, 2011 }} He was killed by Russian security forces outside the village of Serzhen-Yurt, Chechnya on 21 April 2011. ==Early life== Although little is reliably known of Muhannad’s early life, he was born in 1969 and hailed from the [[Medina]] area of Saudi Arabia’s western [[Hejaz]] region.
