Service, c. 1905 | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1874|01|16}} | birth_place = [[Preston, Lancashire|Preston]], [[Lancashire]], England | death_date = {{death date and age|1958|09|11|1874|01|16}} | death_place = [[Lancieux]], [[Côtes-d'Armor]], France | resting_place = [[Lancieux]], [[Côtes-d'Armor]], France | occupation = writer, poet, Canadian Great North adventurer | education = | alma_mater = [[Hillhead High School]] in [[Glasgow]], [[University of Glasgow]] and [[McGill University]] | period = | genre = [[Poetry]], [[Novel]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''Songs of a Sourdough'', ''Rhymes of a Red Cross Man'', ''The Trail of '98'' | spouse = Germaine Bourgoin | module = {{Infobox person|child=yes | father = Robert Service (senior)|mother= Sarah Emily Parker}} | children = Iris Service | relatives = [[Charlotte Service-Longépé]] | <!-- [[Robert Burns]] --> | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }}
'''Robert William Service''' (January 16, 1874 – September 11, 1958) was a British-Canadian poet and writer who has often been called "the Bard of the [[Yukon]]".<ref name=star>"[http://whitehorsestar.com/archive/print/25045/ 1905 R. W. Service: Bard of the Yukon]", ''Whitehorse Star'' online archive, September 11, 2008.</ref><ref name=kilwinning>"[http://www.threetowners.com/Kilwinning/bard_of_the_yukon.htm The Bard of the Yukon] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081027124031/http://www.threetowners.com/Kilwinning/bard_of_the_yukon.htm |date=2008-10-27 }}," Kilwinning, ThreeTowners.com, Web, Apr. 2011</ref> He is best known for his poems "[[The Shooting of Dan McGrew]]" and "[[The Cremation of Sam McGee]]", from his first book, ''[[Songs of a Sourdough]]'' (1907; also published as ''The Spell of the Yukon and Other Verses''). His vivid descriptions of the Yukon and its people made it seem that he was a veteran of the [[Klondike Gold Rush]], instead of the late-arriving bank clerk he actually was. Although his work remains popular, Service's poems were initially received as being crudely comical works.<ref name=answers>"[http://www.answers.com/topic/robert-service Robert W. Service]," Who2 Profiles, Answers.com, Web, Apr. 4, 2011.</ref> {{TOC limit}}
==Life==
===Early life===
Service was born in [[Preston, Lancashire]], England,<ref name="evans" /> the third of ten children. His father, also Robert Service, was a banker from [[Kilwinning]], Scotland, who had been transferred to England.<ref name="electric" />
When he was five, Service was sent to live in Kilwinning with his three maiden aunts and his paternal grandfather, the town's [[postmaster]].<ref name=kilwinning/> There he is said to have composed his first verse, a [[Grace (prayer)|grace]], on his sixth birthday:<ref name=electric/> [[File:RobertWService-plaque-Preston.jpg|thumb|Commemorative Plaque in Preston, England]] At nine, Service re-joined his parents who had moved to [[Glasgow]]. He attended Glasgow's [[Hillhead High School]].<ref name=extended1>"[http://www.robertwservice.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=4&page=1 Extended Biography]," RobertWService.com, July 21, 2003, 1. Web, Apr. 4, 2011</ref>
After leaving school,<ref name=evans>David Evans, "[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/robert-william-service/ Service, Robert William]," ''Canadian Encyclopedia'' (Edmonton: Hurtig, 1988), 1981–1982.</ref> Service joined the [[Commercial Bank of Scotland]] which would later become the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]].<ref name=electric>"[http://www.electricscotland.com/poetry/robert_service.htm Poetry – Robert W. Service]," ElectricScotland.com, Web, Apr. 22, 2011.</ref> He was writing at this time and reportedly already "selling his verses".{{Citation needed|date=November 2013}} He was also reading poetry: [[Robert Browning|Browning]], [[John Keats|Keats]], [[Alfred, Lord Tennyson|Tennyson]], and [[William Makepeace Thackeray|Thackeray]].<ref name=extended1/>
When he was 21, Service travelled to [[Vancouver Island]], [[British Columbia]], with his [[Buffalo Bill]] outfit and dreams of becoming a [[cowboy]]. He drifted around western North America, "wandering from [[California]] to British Columbia,"<ref name=evans/> taking and quitting a series of jobs: "Starving in [[Mexico]], residing in a California [[Brothel|bordello]], farming on Vancouver Island and pursuing unrequited love in [[Vancouver]]."<ref name=enid>"''[http://www.yukonbooks.com/shop/customer/product.php?productid=13891 Robert Service: Under the Spell of the Yukon]''" by Enid Mallory, YukonBooks.com, Web, Apr. 4, 2011</ref> This sometimes required him to leech off his parents' Scottish neighbours and friends who had previously emigrated to Canada.<ref>My Grandma, "Nanny Stiles"</ref>
In 1899, Service was a store clerk in [[Cowichan Bay, British Columbia]]. He mentioned to a customer (Charles H. Gibbons, editor of the Victoria ''Daily [[Times Colonist|Colonist]]'') that he wrote verses, with the result that six poems by "R.S." on the [[Boer Wars]] had appeared in the ''Colonist'' by July 1900<ref name=mitham>Peter J. Mitham, Introduction to "Mossback Minstrelsy: The [http://www.uwo.ca/english/canadianpoetry/cpjrn/vol39/mitham.htm British Columbia Verse of Robert W. Service]," ''Canadian Poetry'' No. 39, UWO, Web, Apr. 5, 2011.</ref> – including "[[s:The March of the Dead|The March of the Dead]]" that would later appear in his first book. (Service's brother, Alick, was a prisoner of the Boers at the time. He had been captured on November 15, 1899, alongside [[Winston Churchill]].)<ref name=mitham/>
The ''Colonist'' also published Service's "[[s:Music in the Bush|Music in the Bush]]" on September 18, 1901, and "[[s:The Little Old Log Cabin|The Little Old Log Cabin]]" on March 16, 1902.<ref name=mitham/>
In her 2006 biography, ''Under the Spell of the Yukon'', Enid Mallory revealed that Service had fallen in love during this period. He was working as a "farm labourer and store clerk when he first met Constance MacLean at a dance in [[Duncan, British Columbia|Duncan B.C.]], where she was visiting her uncle." MacLean lived in Vancouver, on the mainland, so he courted her by mail. Though he was smitten, "MacLean was looking for a man of education and means to support her" so was not that interested. To please her, he took courses at [[McGill University]]'s [[Victoria College, British Columbia|Victoria College]], but failed.<ref name=dawson>Michael Gates, "[http://cityofdawson.com/history-pages/michael-gates/robert-service-secret-love-life Robert Service's Secret Love Life]," Dawson City History, CityofDawson.com, Web, Apr. 5, 2011</ref>
In 1903, down on his luck, Service was hired by a [[Canadian Bank of Commerce]] branch in [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]], British Columbia, using his Commercial Bank letter of reference.<ref name=holloway>Sam Holloway, "[http://www.yukoner.com/service.htm Robert Service and Destiny]," ''The Yukoner Magazine''. Web, Accessed 2008.11.19.</ref> The bank "watched him, gave him a raise, and sent him to [[Kamloops]] in the middle of British Columbia. In Victoria he lived over the bank with a hired piano, and dressed for dinner. In Kamloops, horse country, he played polo. In the fall of 1904, the bank sent him to their [[Whitehorse, Yukon|Whitehorse]] branch in Yukon. With the expense money he bought himself a [[raccoon coat]]."<ref name=extended2>"[http://www.robertwservice.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=4&page=1 Extended [Biography]]," RobertWService.com, July 21, 2003, 2. Web, Apr. 4, 2011</ref>
Throughout this period, Service continued writing and saving his verses: "more than a third of the poems in his first volume had been written before he moved north in 1904."<ref name=smulders>Sharon Smulders, "'[http://journals.hil.unb.ca/index.php/SCL/article/viewArticle/15270/16348 A Man in a World of Men]': The Rough, the Tough, and the Tender in Robert W. Service’s ''Songs of a Sourdough''," ''Studies in Canadian Literature'', 30:1 (2005), UNB.ca, Web, Apr. 5, 2011.</ref>
===Yukon period=== [[Image:Cabin of Robert Service.JPG|thumb|Cabin of Robert Service in Dawson City, Yukon]] [[Whitehorse, Yukon|Whitehorse]] was a frontier town, less than ten years old. Located on the [[Yukon River]] at the [[White Horse Rapids]], it had begun in 1897 as a [[Campsite|campground]] for [[Prospecting|prospectors]] on their way to [[Dawson City]] to join the [[Klondike Gold Rush]]. The railroad that Service rode in on, the [[White Pass and Yukon Route]], had reached Whitehorse only in 1900.<ref>"[http://explorenorth.com/yukon/whitehorse-history.html The History of Whitehorse, Yukon Territory]," ExploretheYukon.com, Web, Apr. 5, 2011.</ref>
Settling in, "Service dreamed and listened to the stories of the great gold rush." He also "took part in the extremely active Whitehorse social life. As was popular at the time he recited at concerts – things like '[[Casey at the Bat]]' and '[[Gunga Din]]', but they were getting stale."<ref name=star/>
One day (Service later wrote), while pondering what to recite at an upcoming church concert he met E.J. "Stroller" White, editor of the ''[[Whitehorse Star]]''. White suggested: "Why don’t you write a poem for it? Give us something about our own bit of earth. We sure would appreciate it. There’s a rich paystreak waiting for someone to work. Why don’t you go in and stake it?"<ref name=star/>
Returning from a walk one Saturday night, Service heard the sounds of revelry from a saloon, and the phrase "A bunch of the boys were whooping it up" popped into his head. Inspired, he ran to the bank to write it down (almost being shot as a burglar), and by the next morning "The Shooting of Dan McGrew" was complete.<ref name=star/>
"A month or so later he heard a gold rush yarn from a Dawson mining man about a fellow who cremated his pal." He spent the night walking in the woods composing "The Cremation of Sam McGee", and wrote it down from memory the next day.<ref name=star/>
Other verses quickly followed. "In the early spring he stood above the heights of Miles Canyon ... the line 'I have gazed on naked grandeur where there’s nothing else to gaze on' came into his mind and again he hammered out a complete poem, "[[s:The Call of the Wild (Service)|The Call of the Wild]]".<ref name=star/> Conversations with locals led Service to write about things he had not seen (some of which had not actually happened) as well.<ref name=kilwinning/> He did not set foot in Dawson City until 1908, arriving in the [[Klondike, Yukon|Klondike]] ten years after the Gold Rush when his renown as a writer was already established.
After having collected enough poems for a book, Service "sent the poems to his father, who had emigrated to [[Toronto]], and asked him to find a printing house so they could make it into a booklet. He enclosed a cheque to cover the costs and intended to give these booklets away to his friends in Whitehorse" for Christmas. His father took the manuscript to William Briggs in Toronto, whose employees loved the book. "The foreman and printers recited the ballads while they worked. A salesman read the proofs out loud as they came off the typesetting machines."<ref name=holloway/> An "enterprising salesman sold 1700 copies in advance orders from galley proofs."<ref name=extended2/> The publisher "sent Robert's cheque back to him and offered a ten percent royalty contract for the book."<ref name=holloway/>
Service's book, ''Songs of a Sourdough'', was "an immediate success."<ref name=evans/> It went through seven printings even before its official release date.<ref name=holloway/> Ultimately, Briggs "sold fifteen impressions in 1907. That same year there was an edition in New York, Philadelphia, and London. The London publisher, [[T. Fisher Unwin]], struck a twenty-third printing in 1910, and thirteen more by 1917."<ref name=extended2/> "Service eventually earned in excess of $100,000 for ''Songs of a Sourdough'' alone"<ref>Sharon Smulders, "'A Man in a World of Men': The Rough, the Tough, and the Tender in Robert W. Service’s ''Songs of a Sourdough''," ''Studies in Canadian Literature'', 30:1 (2005). Web, Apr. 5, 2011.</ref> (equal to about ${{Formatprice|{{Inflation|US|100000|1910|r=-5}}}} today after inflation).
(In the United States, the book would be given the more [[Jack London]]-ish title, ''The Spell of the Yukon and Other Verses'').
"When copies of the book reached Whitehorse, Robert's own minister took him aside to let him know how wicked were his stories. Service hung his head in shame.... But, that summer, tourists from the south arrived in Whitehorse looking for the famous poet; and he autographed many of his books."<ref name=holloway/>
"In 1908, after working for the bank for three years in Whitehorse, he was sent outside on mandatory paid leave for three months, a standard practice for bank employees serving in the Yukon." According to Enid Mallory, he went to Vancouver and looked up Constance MacLean. Now that he was a successful author, she agreed to become engaged to him.<ref name=dawson/>
Following his leave, in 1908 the bank transferred Service to Dawson, where he met veterans of the Gold Rush, now ten years in the past: "they loved to reminisce, and Robert listened carefully and remembered." He used their tales to write a second book of verse, ''Ballads of a Cheechako'', in 1908. "It too was an overwhelming success."<ref name=holloway/>
In 1909, when the bank wanted Service to return to Whitehorse as manager, he decided to resign. "After quitting his job, he rented a small two-room cabin on Eighth Avenue in Dawson City from Mrs. Edna Clarke and began his career as a full-time author."<ref name=dee/> He immediately "went to work on his novel.... He went for walks that lasted all night, slept till mid-afternoon, and sometimes didn't come out of the cabin for days. In five months the novel, called ''The Trail of '98'', was complete and he took it to a publisher in New York." Service's first novel also "immediately became a best-seller."<ref name=holloway/>
Newly wealthy, Service was able to travel to [[Paris]], the [[French Riviera]], [[Hollywood]], and beyond. He returned to Dawson City in 1912 to write his third book of poetry, ''Rhymes of a Rolling Stone'' (1912).<ref name="holloway" /> During that time he became a [[Freemasonry|freemason]], being initiated into Yukon Lodge No. 45 in Dawson.<ref name=freemason>"[http://freemasonry.bcy.ca/biography/service_r_w/robert_service.html Robert W. Service]," Grand Lodge of British Columbia and Yukon, Web, Apr. 4, 2011</ref>
It is unclear what happened between Service and Constance MacLean as no known letters between them exist after Service's departure for Dawson City. In 1912 she "married Leroy Grant, a surveyor and railroad engineer based in [[Prince Rupert, British Columbia|Prince Rupert]]."<ref name=dawson/>
===Later life=== Service left Dawson City for good in 1912.<ref name=holloway/> From 1912 to 1913 he was a [[correspondent]] for the ''[[Toronto Star]]'' during the [[Balkan Wars]].<ref name=freemason />
In 1913, Service moved to Paris, remaining there for the next 15 years. He settled in the [[Latin Quarter, Paris|Latin Quarter]], posing as a painter. In June 1913, he married Parisienne Germaine Bourgoin, daughter of a distillery owner, and they purchased a summer home at [[Lancieux]], [[Côtes-d'Armor]], in the [[Brittany]] region of France.<ref name=extended3>"[http://www.robertwservice.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=4&page=2 Extended [Biography]]," RobertWService.com, July 21, 2003, 3. Web, Apr. 4, 2011</ref> Thirteen years younger than her husband, Germaine Service survived him by 31 years, dying aged 102 in 1989.{{Citation needed|date = October 2015}}
Service was 41 when [[World War I]] broke out; he attempted to enlist, but was turned down "due to [[varicose veins]]."<ref name="electric"/> He briefly covered the war for the ''Toronto Star'' (from December 11, 1915, through January 29, 1916), but "was arrested and nearly executed in an outbreak of spy hysteria in [[Dunkirk]]." He then "worked as a [[Combat medic|stretcher bearer]] and [[Emergency medical technician|ambulance driver]] with the Ambulance Corps of the [[American Red Cross]], until his health broke." Convalescing in Paris, he wrote a new book of mainly war poetry, ''Rhymes of a Red Cross Man'', in 1916. The book was dedicated to the memory of Service's "brother, Lieutenant Albert Service, Canadian Infantry, Killed in Action, France, August 1916."<ref name=extended3/> Robert Service received three medals for his war service: [[1914–15 Star]], [[British War Medal]] and the Victory Medal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://robertwservice.blogspot.fr/2013/10/robert-w-service-1914-1918-great-war.html|title=Robert W. Service 1914–1918 Great War Medals|publisher=}}</ref>
With the end of the war, Service "settled down to being a rich man in Paris.... During the day he would promenade in the best suits, with a [[monocle]]. At night he went out in old clothes with the company of his doorman, a retired policeman, to visit the lowest dives of the city".<ref name=extended3/> During his time in Paris he was reputedly the wealthiest author living in the city, yet was known to dress as a working man and walk the streets, blending in and observing everything around him. Those experiences would be used in his next book of poetry, ''Ballads of a Bohemian'' (1921): "The poems are given in the persona of an American poet in Paris who serves as an ambulance driver and an infantryman in the war. The verses are separated by diary entries over a period of four years."<ref name=extended3/>
In the 1920s, Service began writing thriller novels. ''The Poisoned Paradise, A Romance of Monte Carlo'' (New York, 1922) and ''The Roughneck. A Tale of Tahiti'' (New York, 1923) were both later made into silent movies.<ref name=extended3/> During the winter season, Service used to live in [[Nice]] with his family, where he met British writers, including [[H. G. Wells|H.G. Wells]], A.K. Bruce, [[Somerset Maugham]], [[Rex Ingram (director)|Rex Ingram]], Franck Scully, [[James Joyce]], Franck Harris, and Frieda Laurence, who all spent their winters in the French Riviera, and he wrote that he had been lucky to have had lunch with [[Colette]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://robertwservice.blogspot.com/p/biographie.html|title=Biographie|publisher=}}</ref> [[File:Robert Service's memorial, Kilwinning.JPG|thumb|Robert Service Memorial, Kilwinning, Ayrshire.]] In 1930, Service returned to Kilwinning, to erect a memorial to his family in the town cemetery.<ref name=electric/> He also visited the [[Soviet Union|USSR]] in the 1930s and later wrote a satirical "Ballad of [[Lenin's Mausoleum|Lenin's Tomb]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Frgm5QodnFoC&pg=PA210&lpg=PA210&dq=Lenin's%20Tomb%20%22Robert%20W%20Service%22&source=bl&ots=H9MOHv4bdC&sig=f7vECtBi3QxZV5PuUE6IaXYrJMg&hl=en&ei=DjDuTPrVJZChOumrxIoK&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CCAQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Lenin's%20Tomb%20%22Robert%20W%20Service%22&f=false|title=Comrades!: A History of World Communism|first=Robert|last=Service|date=1 January 2007|publisher=Harvard University Press|via=Google Books}}</ref> For this reason his poetry was never translated into [[Russian language|Russian]] in the USSR, and he was never mentioned in Soviet encyclopedias.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://publ.lib.ru/ARCHIVES/S/SERVIS_Robert_Uil'yam/_Servis_R.U..html|title=Сервис Роберт Уильям|publisher=}}</ref>
Service's second trip to the Soviet Union "was interrupted by news of the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]]. Service fled across Poland, [[Latvia]], [[Estonia]] and the [[Baltic Sea|Baltic]] to [[Stockholm]]. He wintered in [[Nice]] with his family, then fled France for Canada." Not long after, the [[Nazism|Nazis]] invaded France, and "arrived at his home in Lancieux ... looking specifically for the poet who had mocked [[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]] in newspaper verse."<ref name=extended4>"[http://www.robertwservice.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=4&page=3 Extended [Biography]]," RobertWService.com, July 21, 2003, 4. Web, Apr. 4, 2011</ref>
During [[World War II]], Service lived in [[California]], "and Hollywood had him join with other celebrities in helping the morale of troops – visiting [[United States Army|US Army]] camps to recite his poems. He was also asked to play himself in the movie ''[[The Spoilers (1942 film)|The Spoilers]]'' (1942), working alongside [[Marlene Dietrich]], [[John Wayne]] and [[Randolph Scott]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://robertwservice.blogspot.fr/2013/03/the-spoilers-starring-robert-w-service.html|title="The Spoilers" starring Robert W. Service|publisher=}}</ref> "He was thrilled to play a scene with Marlene Dietrich."<ref name=extended4/> After the war, Service and his wife returned to his home in Brittany, to find it destroyed. They rebuilt, and he lived there until his death in 1958, though he wintered in [[Monte Carlo]] on the [[French Riviera]].<ref name=extended4/> Service's wife and daughter, Iris, travelled to the Yukon in 1946 "and visited Whitehorse and Dawson City, which by then was becoming a ghost town. Service could not bring himself to go back. He preferred to remember the town as it had been."<ref name=star/>
Service wrote prolifically during his last years, publishing six books of verse from 1949 to 1955. A book he had written in 1956 was published posthumously.<ref>See Selected Works – Poetry</ref> In the spring of 1958, not long before Service died, Canadian broadcaster [[Pierre Berton]] recorded many hours of autobiographical television interview for the [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]], in Service's Monte Carlo flat. At this occasion, Service recited The Shooting of Dan McGrew and [[The Cremation of Sam McGee]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://robertwservice.blogspot.fr/2013/05/the-cremation-of-sam-mcgee-recited-by.html|title=The Cremation of Sam McGee Recited by Robert W. Service|publisher=}}</ref> {{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
Service lived in [[Monaco]] from 1947 to 1958.<ref name="lobsmonaco">{{cite news |first=Raphael|last=Brun|title= C’était un poète aventurier |newspaper=[[L'Observateur de Monaco]] |date=September 30, 2015}}</ref> He wrote two volumes of [[autobiography]] – ''Ploughman of the Moon'' (1945) and ''Harper of Heaven'' (1948). He died in Lancieux and is buried in the local cemetery.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://robertwservice.blogspot.fr/2013/11/robert-w-services-tombstone.html/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-02-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160422184220/http://robertwservice.blogspot.fr/2013/11/robert-w-services-tombstone.html |archivedate=2016-04-22 |df= }}</ref>
==Writing== Robert Service wrote the most commercially successful poetry of the century.{{according to whom|date=May 2012}} Yet his most popular works "were considered [[doggerel]] by the literary set."<ref name=answers/> During his lifetime, he was nicknamed "the Canadian [[Rudyard Kipling|Kipling]]."<ref name="evans"/> – yet that may have been a double-edged compliment. As [[T. S. Eliot]] has said, "we have to defend Kipling against the charge of excessive lucidity," "the charge of being a '[[journalist]]' appealing only to the commonest collective emotion," and "the charge of writing [[jingle]]s."<ref>T.S. Eliot, Introduction to ''[[A Choice of Kipling's Verse]]'' (London: Faber, 1941), 6.</ref> All those charges, and more, could be levelled against Service's best known and best loved works. {{according to whom|date=May 2018}}
Certainly Service's verse was derivative of Kipling's. In "The Cremation of Sam McGee", for instance, he uses the form of Kipling's "[[The Ballad of East and West]]".
In his [[E. J. Pratt]] lecture "Silence In the Sea," critic [[Northrop Frye]] argued that Service's verse was not "serious poetry," but something else he called "popular poetry": "the idioms of popular and serious poetry remain inexorably distinct." Popular poems, he thought, "preserve a surface of explicit statement" – either being "proverbial, like Kipling's '[[If—|If]]' or [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow|Longfellow]]'s '[[A Psalm of Life|Song of Life]]' or [[Robert Burns|Burns]]'s '[[Is There for Honest Poverty|For A' That]]'," or dealing in "conventionally poetic themes, like the [[pastoral]] themes of [[James Whitcomb Riley]], or the adventurous themes of Robert Service."<ref>Northrop Frye, "[http://northropfrye-thebushgarden.blogspot.com/2009/02/silence-in-sea.html Silence in the Sea]," ''The Bush Garden'' (Toronto, Anansi, 1971, 189.</ref>
Service himself did not call his work poetry. "Verse, not poetry, is what I was after ... something the man in the street would take notice of and the sweet old lady would paste in her album; something the schoolboy would spout and the fellow in the pub would quote. Yet I never wrote to please anyone but myself; it just happened. I belonged to the simple folks whom I liked to please."<ref name=star/>
In his autobiography, Service described his method of writing at his Dawson City cabin. "I used to write on the coarse rolls of paper used by paper-hangers, pinning them on the wall and printing my verses in big charcoal letters. Then I would pace back and forth before them, repeating them, trying to make them perfect. I wanted to make them appeal to the eye as well as to the ear. I tried to avoid any literal quality."<ref name=star/>
One remarkable thing about both of Service's best-known ballads is how easily he wrote them. When writing about composing "The Shooting of Dan McGrew", 'easy' was exactly the word he used: "For it came so easy to me in my excited state that I was amazed at my facility. It was as if someone was whispering in my ear."<ref name=star/> And this was just after someone had tried to shoot him. He continued: "As I wrote stanza after stanza, the story seemed to evolve itself. It was a marvelous experience. Before I crawled into my bed at five in the morning, my ballad was in the bag."<ref name=star/>
Similarly, when he wrote "The Cremation of Sam McGee", the verses just flowed: "I took the woodland trail, my mind seething with excitement and a strange ecstasy.... As I started in: There are strange things done in the midnight sun, verse after verse developed with scarce a check ... and when I rolled happily into bed, my ballad was cinched. Next day, with scarcely any effort of memory I put it on paper."<ref name=star/>
In 1926, [[Archibald MacMechan]], Professor of English at Canada's [[Dalhousie University]], pronounced on Service's Yukon books in his ''Headwaters of Canadian Literature'':
:The sordid, the gross, the bestial, may sometimes be redeemed by the touch of genius; but that Promethean touch is not in Mr. Service. In manner he is frankly imitative of Kipling's barrack-room balladry; and imitation is an admission of inferiority. 'Sourdough' is Yukon slang for the provident old-timer ... It is a convenient term for this wilfully violent kind of verse without the power to redeem the squalid themes it treats. ''The Ballads of a Cheechako'' is a second installment of sourdoughs, while his novel ''The Trail of '98'' is simply sourdough prose.<ref name=macmechan>Archibald MacMechan, ''Headwaters of Canadian Literature (Toronto: New Canadian Library, 1974), 219–221.</ref>
MacMechan did give grudging respect to Service's World War I poetry, conceding that his style went well with that subject, and that "his ''Rhymes of a Red Cross Man'' are an advance on his previous volumes. He has come into touch with the grimmest of realities; and while his radical faults have not been cured, his rude lines drive home the truth that he has seen."<ref name=macmechan/>
Reviewing Service's ''Rhymes of a Rebel'' in 1952, Frye remarked that the book "interests me chiefly because ... I have noticed so much verse in exactly the same [[idiom]], and I wonder how far Mr. Service's books may have influenced it. There was a time, fifty years ago," he added," when Robert W.Service represented, with some accuracy, the general level of poetic experience in Canada, as far as the popular reader was concerned.... there has been a prodigious, and, I should think, a permanent, change in public taste."<ref>Northrop Frye, "[http://northropfrye-thebushgarden.blogspot.com/2009/02/from-letters-in-canada-1952.html Letters from Canada – 1952]," ''The Bush Garden'' (Toronto, Anansi, 1971, 189.</ref>
Service has also been noted for his use of [[ethnonym]]s that would normally be considered offensive "slurs", but with no insult apparently intended. Words used in Service's poetry include ''[[List of terms used for Germans#Jerry|jerries]]'' (Germans), ''dago'' (Italian), ''[[pickaninny]]'' (in reference to a Mozambican infant), ''[[Chinook Jargon|cheechako]]'' (newcomer to the Yukon and Alaska gold fields, usually from the U.S.), ''[[nigger]]'' (black person), ''[[squaw]]'' (Aboriginal woman), and ''[[Jap]]'' (Japanese).
==Recognition== [[File:Bust of Robert Service Whitehorse Yukon.jpg|thumb|A bust of Service in Whitehorse]] Robert W. Service has been honoured with schools named for him including [[Robert Service High School]] in [[Anchorage, Alaska]], Robert Service Senior Public School (Middle/ Jr. High) in Toronto, [[Ontario]]<ref>[http://www.tdsb.on.ca/scripts/Schoolasp.asp?schno=4724 Robert Service Sr PS]</ref> and Robert Service School in Dawson City.<ref>[http://www.education.gov.yk.ca/psb/directory.html Yukon Public School Directory]</ref>
He was also honoured on a [[List of people on stamps of Canada|Canadian postage stamp]] in 1976. The [[Arterial roads in Whitehorse, Yukon#Robert Service Way|Robert Service Way]], a main road in Whitehorse, is named after him.{{Citation needed|date = October 2015}}
Additionally, the Bard & Banker public house in Victoria is dedicated to him, the building having at one time been a Canadian Bank of Commerce branch where Service was employed while residing in the city.
Service's first novel, ''The Trail of '98'', was made into a movie by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]], directed by [[Clarence Brown]].<ref name=extended3/> "''[[The Trail of '98|Trail of '98]]'' starring [[Dolores del Río]], [[Ralph Forbes]] and [[Karl Dane]] in 1929 ... was the first talking picture dealing with the Klondike gold rush and was acclaimed at the time by critics for depicting the Klondike as it really was."<ref name=dee>Dee Newman, "[http://the8thdimension.blogspot.com/2011/03/robert-services-little-cabin.html Robert Service's Little Cabin]," The Eighth Dimension (blog), Mar. 3, 2011. Web, Apr. 4, 2011</ref>
In 1968 Canadian-born country singer [[Hank Snow]] recorded recitations of eight of Service's longer poems for an album entitled Tales of the Yukon. The album was released by RCA Victor. Snow and other musicians including [[Chet Atkins]] and [[Chubby Wise]] provided background music.<ref>RCA Victor LSP-4032</ref>
Folksinger [[Country Joe McDonald]] set some of Service's World War I poetry (plus "The March of the Dead" from his first book), to music for his 1971 studio album, ''[[War War War]]''.{{Citation needed|date = October 2015}}
The [[Canadian whiskey]] [[Yukon Jack (liqueur)|Yukon Jack]] incorporated various excerpts of his writings in their ads in the 1970s, one of which was the first four lines of his poem, ''"The Men Who Don't Fit In"''.<ref>http://www.vintagepaperads.com/assets/images/EH0654.jpg</ref>
The town of [[Lancieux]], where he used to come every summer, organized several recognitions to the memory of Robert W. Service. One of the streets of [[Lancieux]] has been called Robert Service Street. On July 13, 1990, a commemorative tablet was unveiled at the Lancieux Office du Tourisme by the daughter of the poet: Iris Service. An evening of celebration was organized afterwards with a dinner attended by many guests from Scotland and the Yukon. A few years later, on May 18, 2002 the school of Lancieux in Brittany took the name of "École Robert W. Service". [[Charlotte Service-Longépé]] the great granddaughter and the granddaughter of the poet attended the dedication ceremony and made a speech.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.robertwservice.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=947&page=1/|title=Hommage – Books and Poetry > The Anne Longepe Collection - Archives - RobertWService.Com|first=Richard|last=Hall|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.robertwservice.com/modules/smartsection/item.php?itemid=946&keywords=charlotte Evening with the Bard]; accessed 2017-04-06</ref> Since 2000, the towns of [[Lancieux]] and [[Whitehorse, Yukon|Whitehorse]] are sister cities, due to Robert W. Service's life and work in both places.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehorse.ca/departments/parks-and-community-development/sister-city-program-lancieux-france|title=Whitehorse, YT : Sister City Program – Lancieux, France|publisher=}}</ref>
Radio humorist and raconteur [[Jean Shepherd]] recorded a collection of Robert Service's poems, ''Jean Shepherd Reads the Poems of Robert Service''.<ref>http://www.folkways.si.edu/jean-shepherd-reads-poems-of-robert-service/poetry/album/smithsonian</ref>
[[Margaret Rutherford]] recited most of "[[The Shooting of Dan McGrew]]" in the 1964 [[Ealing Studios]] film ''[[Murder Most Foul]]''.
===Dawson City cabin=== Robert Service lived from 1909 to 1912 in a small two-room cabin on 8th Avenue which he rented from Edna Clarke in Dawson City.<ref name=dee/> His prosperity allowed him the luxury of a telephone.{{citation needed|date = January 2014}} Service eventually decided he could not return to Dawson, as it would not be as he remembered it. He wrote in his autobiography:
:"Only yesterday an air-line offered to fly me up there in two days, and I refused. It would have saddened me to see dust and rust where once hummed a rousing town; hundreds where were thousands; tumbledown cabins, mouldering warehouses."<ref name=dee/>
After Service left for Europe, the [[Imperial Order of the Daughters of the Empire]] (I.O.D.E.) took care of the cabin until 1971, preserving it. In 1971 it was taken over by [[Parks Canada]], which maintains it, including its sod roof, as a tourist attraction.<ref>{{cite web|title= Parks Canada, Robert Service Cabin, Classified Federal Heritage Building Dawson, Yukon Territory |url= http://www.pc.gc.ca/apps/dfhd/page_fhbro_eng.aspx?id=3198 |publisher= Parks Canada|date= 2012-03-15|accessdate= 2015-10-17}}</ref>
Irish-born actor Tom Byrne created ''The Robert Service Show'' which was presented in the front yard of the cabin, starting in 1976. This was very popular for summer visitors and set the standard for Robert Service recitations. A resurgence in sales of Service's works followed the institution of these performances.{{citation needed|date = January 2014}} Byrne discontinued the show at the cabin in 1995, moving it to a Front Street storefront. Since 2004 the show has been held at the Westmark Hotel in Dawson City during the summer months.
At the Service Cabin, local Dawson entertainers dressed in period costumes and employed by Parks Canada offer biographical information and recite Service's poetry for visitors.

{{Infobox NASCAR driver | name = Ryan Reed | image = RyanReed2018Johnsonville180.jpg | caption = Reed at [[Road America]] in 2018 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1993|8|12}} | birth_place = [[Bakersfield, California]] | height = | weight = | achievements = | awards = | Total_Cup_Races = 1 | Years_In_Cup = 1 | Cup_Car_Team = | Prev_Cup_Pos = 55th | Prev_Cup_Year = 2016 | Best_Cup_Pos = 55th ([[2016 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series|2016]]) | First_Cup_Race = [[2016 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series|2016]] [[2016 Hellmann's 500|Hellmann's 500]] ([[Talladega Superspeedway|Talladega]]) | Last_Cup_Race = | First_Cup_Win = | Last_Cup_Win = | Cup_Wins = 0 | Cup_Top_Tens = 0 | Cup_Poles = 0 | Total_Busch_Races = 171 | Years_In_Busch = 6 | Busch_Car_Team = | Prev_Busch_Pos = 11th | Prev_Busch_Year = 2018 | Best_Busch_Pos = 6th ([[2016 NASCAR Xfinity Series|2016]]) | First_Busch_Race = [[2013 NASCAR Nationwide Series|2013]] [[ToyotaCare 250]] ([[Richmond International Raceway|Richmond]]) | Last_Busch_Race = {{Latest NASCAR Busch}} | First_Busch_Win = [[2015 NASCAR Xfinity Series|2015]] [[Alert Today Florida 300]] ([[Daytona International Speedway|Daytona]]) | Last_Busch_Win = [[2017 NASCAR Xfinity Series|2017]] [[PowerShares QQQ 300]] ([[Daytona International Speedway|Daytona]]) | Busch_Wins = 2 | Busch_Top_Tens = 27 | Busch_Poles = 0 | Total_Truck_Races = 1 | Years_In_Truck = 1 | Truck_Car_Team = | Prev_Truck_Pos = 115th | Prev_Truck_Year = 2016 | Best_Truck_Pos = 61st ([[2012 NASCAR Camping World Truck Series|2012]]) | First_Truck_Race = [[2012 NASCAR Camping World Truck Series|2012]] [[Smith's 350]] ([[Las Vegas Motor Speedway|Las Vegas]]) | Last_Truck_Race = | First_Truck_Win = | Last_Truck_Win = | Truck_Wins = 0 | Truck_Top_Tens = 0 | Truck_Poles = 0 | updated = November 17, 2018 }} '''Ryan Reed''' (born August 12, 1993) is an American professional [[stock car racing]] driver. He last competed full-time in the [[NASCAR Xfinity Series]], driving the No. 16 [[Ford Mustang]] for [[Roush Fenway Racing]]. ==Racing career== [[File:16 Ryan Reed 2016 Road America 180.jpg|thumb|left|Reed's No. 16 at [[Road America]] in 2016]] Reed began racing at age 4, and in 2009 won the [[Legends car racing|Legends Division]] championship at [[Irwindale Speedway]]. In 2010, he entered the [[late model|Super Late Model]] Division, and became the track's youngest Super Late Model winner, and won Rookie of the Year. At age 17, Reed moved from [[Bakersfield, California]] to [[Mooresville, North Carolina]] to focus on racing. In 2011, Reed ran in various series, including the Pro Allstars Series, [[Whelen All-American Series]] and the [[K&N Pro Series East]]. During the year, Reed was expected to run a Late Model as a [[driver development program|development driver]] with [[Kyle Busch Motorsports]] until his diagnosis with [[type 1 diabetes]].{{cite web|last=James|first=Brant|url=http://espn.go.com/racing/nascar/nationwide/story/_/id/9207284/nascar-ryan-reed-race-diabetes|title=Ryan Reed's race against diabetes|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=April 24, 2013|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} In December 2011, Reed was announced as a part-time driver in the [[ARCA Racing Series]] for [[Venturini Motorsports]].{{cite web|url=http://www.venturinimotorsports.com/news/index.cfm?cid=54366#sthash.DUHJRXvI.dpuf|title=Ryan Reed is Set to Run in the 2012 ARCA Racing Series Season with Venturini Motorsports|work=[[Venturini Motorsports]]|date=December 10, 2011|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} Reed ran 14 events in the team's No. 15,{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/rquery?id=reedry01&trk=t0&series=A|title=ARCA Racing Series Results (races)|work=Racing-Reference|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} recording six top tens and a 14th-place points finish.{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/yeardet/2012/A|title=ARCA Racing Series standings for 2012|work=Racing-Reference|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} In 2012, Reed made his [[NASCAR]] [[Camping World Truck Series]] debut at [[Las Vegas Motor Speedway]] in the No. 5 for [[Wauters Motorsports]],{{cite web|url=http://www.skirtsandscuffs.com/2012/09/ryan-reed-to-make-nascar-top-tier.html|title=Ryan Reed to Make NASCAR Top-Tier Series Debut with Wauters Motorsports|work=Skirts and Scuffs|date=September 24, 2012|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} finishing 17th.{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/race/2012_Smiths_350/C|title=2012 Smith's 350|work=Racing-Reference|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} In 2013, Reed joined [[Roush Fenway Racing]] in the [[Nationwide Series]], driving No. 16 [[Ford Mustang]], and running various races during the [[2013 NASCAR Nationwide Series|2013 season]] with [[Eli Lilly and Company]] and the [[American Diabetes Association]]'s Drive to Stop Diabetes campaign as sponsor. Reed made his Nationwide debut in the [[ToyotaCare 250]] at [[Richmond International Raceway]],{{cite web|last=Bailey|first=Alan|url=http://www.americanracingnetwork.com/2013/04/ryan-reed-to-make-nationwide-debut-at-richmond/|title=Ryan Reed to make Nationwide debut at Richmond|publisher=American Racing Network|date=April 22, 2013|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} finishing 16th. Reed ran six races during the season,{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/drivdet/reedry01/2013/B|title=2013 NASCAR Nationwide Series Results|work=Racing-Reference|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} recording his first top-ten after finishing 9th in the [[Virginia 529 College Savings 250]] at Richmond.{{cite web|last=Reed|first=Ryan|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/10/09/health/human-factor-ryan-reed/|title=NASCAR driver races to stop diabetes|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=October 9, 2013|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} On October 11, 2013, Roush Fenway Racing announced that Reed would run the No. 16 in the [[2014 NASCAR Nationwide Series]] season full-time, with Lilly Diabetes and the ADA sponsoring full-time. The sponsorship has been reported to be worth $5 million annually.{{cite web|url=http://www.roushfenway.com/?q=story/roush-fenway-racing-announces-ryan-reed-driver-no-16-american-diabetes-association-drive-stop-|title=Roush Fenway Racing Announces Ryan Reed As The Driver Of The No. 16 American Diabetes Association Drive To Stop Diabetes SM Presented By Lilly Diabetes Ford Mustang For The 2014 NASCAR Nationwide Series Season|work=[[Roush Fenway Racing]]|date=October 11, 2013|accessdate=March 17, 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Schoettle|first1=Anthony|title=Sponsorship of diabetic NASCAR driver may help Lilly regain market share|url=http://www.ibj.com/articles/52145-sponsorship-of-diabetic-nascar-driver-may-help-lilly-regain-market-share|website=[[Indianapolis Business Journal|ibj.com]]|publisher=[[Indianapolis Business Journal]]|accessdate=10 March 2015|date=March 7, 2015}} [[File:Reed17.jpg|thumb|left|Reed during practice at [[New Hampshire Motor Speedway]] in 2017]] On February 21, 2015, Reed won his first Xfinity Series race in the season-opening [[Alert Today Florida 300]] at [[Daytona International Speedway]], pushed by teammate [[Chris Buescher]] past leader [[Brad Keselowski]] on the final lap of the race. On June 20, 2015, Reed won his first career [[ARCA Racing Series]] race in the Scott 150 at [[Chicagoland Speedway]] driving for [[Lira Motorsports]]. Reed led the final 70 laps of the 100-lap race, capturing the Valvoline Lap Leader award. It was the first ARCA Series win for [[Lira Motorsports]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arcaracing.com/articles/1996618-reed-takes-lira-motorsports-to-victory-lane-at-chicagoland|title=Reed takes Lira Motorsports to victory lane at Chicagoland|publisher=ARCA|date=June 20, 2015|accessdate=October 31, 2016}} Reed ended the 2015 Xfinity season a distant 10th in points, the Daytona victory being his only top 10 of the year. Reed ran the full Xfinity season in 2016. In early 2016, Reed attempted the Truck race at Daytona driving the No. 58 [[Ford F-150]] for [[Lira Motorsports]], but failed to qualify.{{cite web|url=http://www.jayski.com/cts/next/2016/pdfs/cts_01daytona2016lineup.pdf|title=Starting Line Up by Row - Daytona International Speedway - 17th Annual NextEra Energy Resources 250|work=[[Jayski's Silly Season Site]]|accessdate=February 19, 2016|format=PDF}} In, 2016, Reed finished with 7 top 10s, increasing his total top 10 count from 3 to 10. Reed finished 6th in points. On September 28, 2016, it was announced by RFR that Reed would attempt his [[Sprint Cup Series]] debut at Talladega in the [[2016 Hellmann's 500|Hellmann's 500]], driving the No. 99 [[Ford Fusion (Americas)|Ford Fusion]].{{cite web|last=Wilhelm|first=Chase|url=http://www.foxsports.com/nascar/story/xfinity-driver-ryan-reed-to-attempt-sprint-cup-debut-at-talladega-roush-fenway-racing-092816|title=XFINITY driver Ryan Reed to attempt Sprint Cup debut at Talladega|publisher=[[Foxsports.com]]|date=September 28, 2016|accessdate=September 28, 2016}} Reed became the first driver in NASCAR to manage his diabetes and race in the Sprint Cup Series. After starting 18th, he finished 26th.{{cite web|url=http://racing-reference.info/race/2016_Hellmanns_500/W|title=2016 Hellmann's 500|work=Racing-Reference|accessdate=October 24, 2016}} [[File:Ryan_Reed_Daytona_Win.jpg|thumb|left|Reed celebrates his Daytona Xfinity win in 2017, his second at the track]] On February 25, 2017, Reed won the Xfinity Series' season-opening race, the PowerShares QQQ 300, at Daytona. His second career Xfinity Series victory, Reed survived a race that eliminated multiple drivers in wrecks, with only ten cars of the field of forty having little to no damage.{{cite web|last=Menzer|first=Joe|url=http://www.foxsports.com/nascar/story/xxxxxxxx-avoids-calamity-to-win-wreck-filled-nxs-race-at-daytona-022517|title=Ryan Reed avoids calamity to win wreck-filled NXS race at Daytona|publisher=[[Foxsports.com]]|date=February 25, 2017|accessdate=February 25, 2017}} At the June Michigan race weekend, Reed substituted for [[Trevor Bayne]] in the No. 6 Cup car during practice as Bayne's wife, Ashton, was expecting their second child.{{cite web|last=McAssey|first=Pat|url=http://nesn.com/2017/06/ryan-reed-ready-to-drive-no-6-if-trevor-bayne-called-to-delivery-room/|title=Ryan Reed Ready To Drive No. 6 If Trevor Bayne Called To Delivery Room|publisher=[[New England Sports Network]]|date=June 16, 2017|accessdate=June 16, 2017}} On October 15, It was announced that long time sponsor [[Eli Lilly and Company|Lilly Diabetes]] will be pulling out of the sport leaving the 16 car unsponsored for 2019.{{cite web |url=https://racer.com/2018/10/15/lilly-diabetes-to-end-roush-sponsorship/ |title=Lilly Diabetes to end Roush sponsorship |first=Kelly |last=Crandall |website=Racer.com |date=October 15, 2018 |accessdate=December 3, 2018}} Despite the controversies with Conor Daly's father insensitive racial remarks back in the 1980s. It is unknown if Reed will have an Xfinity ride for the 2019 season. ==Personal life== Reed's father, [[Mark Reed (racing driver)|Mark Reed]], is a former NASCAR driver who has two K&N West wins and two Cup starts.[http://www.racing-reference.info/driver/Mark_Reed Mark Reed racing profile] Reed is the youngest of four children. In February 2011, Reed was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes, and doctors stated he would be unable to race again.{{cite web|last=Pockrass|first=Bob|url=http://www.sportingnews.com/nascar/story/2013-12-26/diabetic-nascar-driver-ryan-reed-first-full-nationwide-season-roush-racing|title=Diabetic driver Ryan Reed ready for first full Nationwide season|publisher=''[[Sports Illustrated]]''|date=December 26, 2013|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} As a result, Reed became a diabetes advocate, and established the foundation Ryan's Mission.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalspeedsportnews.com/nascar/nationwide/ryan-reed-joins-roush-fenway-racing/|title=Ryan Reed Joins Roush Fenway Racing|work=[[National Speed Sport News]]|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} Reed installed a drink system in his car, along with a [[blood glucose monitoring|blood glucose monitor]] on the car's dashboard which displays data from a wireless device attached to Reed's stomach.{{cite news|last=Haug|first=Jim|url=http://www.news-journalonline.com/article/20140220/NASCAR/140229902|title=Nationwide rookie driver Ryan Reed tackles Daytona, and racing career, with diabetes|newspaper=[[The Daytona Beach News-Journal]]|date=February 20, 2014|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} During races, Reed would monitor his blood glucose levels,{{cite web|url=http://www.stopdiabetes.com/5-ways-to-act/ambassadors/ryan-reed.html|title=Ryan Reed|work=Stop Diabetes|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} while Roush engine tuner Craig Herrmann would inject Reed with [[insulin therapy|insulin]] during [[pit stop]]s. Reed is one of three drivers in a national racing series with type 1 diabetes, along with [[IndyCar Series]] drivers [[Charlie Kimball]] and [[Conor Daly]].{{cite web|author=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://espn.go.com/racing/nascar/nationwide/story/_/id/9809738/diabetic-ryan-reed-gets-full-ride-roush-fenway-racing|title=Diabetic Ryan Reed gets Roush ride|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=October 11, 2013|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} ==Motorsports career results== ===Career summary=== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! [[File:Dr. Sandra Palmer.jpg|thumb|Sandra Palmer]]
'''Sandra Marie Palmer''' (born August 4, 1969) is a Jamaican entrepreneur who founded [[information technology company]] SSP APTEC in 1997, eventually opening a branch in [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] in 2002.<ref name="Vision">{{cite news|last1=Hall|first1=Diana|title=Dr Sandra Palmer-Peart A vision for excellence|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/magazines/allwoman/125984_Dr-Sandra-Palmer-Peart-A-vision-for-excellence|accessdate=28 May 2015|agency=All Woman|publisher=Jamaica Observer|date=August 6, 2007}}</ref> In 2014, she founded Soulmates, a boutique match-making social club for the affluent and Peak Performance International, a consulting firm.
She currently lectures New Ventures and Entrepreneurship at the Mona School of Business and Management at the [[University of the West Indies, Mona]] and Managerial Economics and New Venture Creation at [[Northern Caribbean University]]. In 2010, the [[World Bank]] named her as one of the top female entrepreneurs in [[Latin America]] and the [[Caribbean]].<ref name="WB Source">{{cite web|author1=World Bank|title=Women’s Economic Opportunities in the Formal Private Sector in Latin America and the Caribbean: A Focus on Entrepreneurship|url=http://idbdocs.iadb.org/wsdocs/getdocument.aspx?docnum=35278574|website=World Bank|accessdate=28 May 2015|pages=121-9|date=2010}}</ref>
On August 2, 2016, Dr. Palmer was appointed CEO and Senior Partner at Above or Beyond (formerly The Job Bank). In this new role as CEO and Senior Partner, Dr. Palmer will leverage her experience in business and academia to lead the organisation during this transitional period and beyond. The new organisation plans to build on its past legacy in the area of human capital development by strengthening its internal capacity and expanding its reach in the Caribbean.
==Early life and education== Sandra was born in the small, rural community of Topsham located in [[Manchester, Jamaica]].<ref name="TVJ">{{cite web|author1=Smile Jamaica|title=Off The Shelf - On Seraph Wings|url=http://www.televisionjamaica.com/Programmes/SmileJamaica.aspx/Videos/40983|website=Television Jamaica|publisher=Television Jamaica|accessdate=28 May 2015|format=Video|date=May 12, 2015}}</ref> She has two younger brothers. She attended Coley’s Mountain Primary School from 1974 – 1980. Upon failing her first attempt at the Common Entrance Examination, she was sent to Nazareth All Age School in 1980 where she was successful in her second attempt at the Common Entrance Examination moving on to Bishop Gibson High School for Girls in Mandeville in 1981. She graduated from Bishop Gipson in 1986.
After spending time briefly in the banking sector, Sandra began pursuing tertiary education in 1989 at the [[University of the West Indies, Mona]]. She graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] Honours degree majoring in [[History]], [[Political Science]] and [[Economics]].<ref name="Vision" />
In 1997, she earned her [[Masters of Business Administration]] (with Distinction) from [[Nova Southeastern University]] at the H. Wayne Huizenga School of Business and Entrepreneurship, where she specialized in General Management. In 2004, she completed her [[Doctorate]] in [[Business Administration]] with honours from [[Nova Southeastern University]]’s H. Wayne Huizenga School of Business and Entrepreneurship where she specialized in [[Information Technology Management]].<ref name="Vision" /> Her doctoral dissertation entitled "A Study of the Inclination of Jamaican Employees to Opt for Telework: A Comparison with Findings for United Kingdom Employees" was published in 2004.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Palmer-Peart|first1=Sandra|title=A study on the inclination of Jamaican employees to opt for telework: A comparison with findings for United Kingdom employees|date=2004|publisher=Nova Southeastern University|location=Nova Southeastern University|pages=362|url=https://www.editlib.org/dissertations/topics/labor_economics/}}</ref>
==Career and entrepreneurial pursuits== Palmer worked at the [[National Commercial Bank]] for four years until she resigned in 1990 to focus completely on her university education. After completing her first degree she began working at the information technology firm WTG-APTEC. In 1996, she left and joined [[GraceKennedy]]’s InfoGrace team as corporate account executive.{{cn|date=September 2016}}
In October of 1997, Palmer started SSP APTEC Limited in [[Kingston, Jamaica]], an [[information technology company]], which provided audio-visual equipment.<ref name="WB Source" /> The firm also advised the top management of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and institutions on issues of strategy, organizational operations and technology.<ref>{{cite web|title=IBM Business Partners Information|url=http://www.ibm.com/planetwide/jm/|website=IBM|accessdate=28 May 2015|format=Webpage}}</ref> In November 2002, she expanded to Florida under the name SSP APTEC Inc. and remained in that market for 10 years. In March 2012, after almost two decades, she suspended both companies and went into academia full-time.
Palmer was acknowledged in the [[World Bank]] report, "Women’s Economic Opportunities in the Formal Private Sector in Latin America and the Caribbean: A focus on Entrepreneurship in 2010 for her entrepreneurial pursuits and was cited as one of Jamaica’s most successful female entrepreneurs".<ref name="WB Source" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Lack of women in IT prompts calls for education reform|url=http://www.afr.com/technology/enterprise-it/lack-of-women-in-it-prompts-calls-for-education-reform-20150222-137gil|website=AFR Weekend|accessdate=27 June 2015}}</ref>
In 2014, she founded two companies: '''Peak Performance International''', which offers [[executive coaching]], business and life coaching, motivational and keynote speaking as well as management consulting and '''Soulmates''' in 2014, an exclusive match making site, which finds love for the affluent and successful individual who is seeking a meaningful long-term relationship.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Nadine|title=Finding Soulmates|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/magazines/allwoman/Finding-Soulmates_15949031|accessdate=8 July 2015|agency=All Woman|publisher=The Jamaica Observer|date=February 10, 2014}}</ref> As a core philosophy, Sandra believes that "only the companies who rethink their strategies and put plans in place to respond to the new business environment will remain viable or even survive."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Roache|first1=Alicia|title=SSP Aptec to move from Red Hills Road HQ into smaller office|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/business/SSP-Aptec-to-move-from-Red-Hills-Road-HQ-into-smaller-office_8277032|accessdate=28 May 2015|publisher=Jamaica Observer|date=January 9, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Smile Jamaica|title=A Nw Way To Find Love|url=http://www.televisionjamaica.com/Programmes/SmileJamaica.aspx/Videos/32793|website=Television Jamaica|publisher=Television Jamaica|accessdate=6 July 2015|format=Video|date=February 2, 2014}}</ref>
In August 2016, Dr. Sandra Palmer became Chief Executive Officer and Senior Partner at Above or Beyond (formerly The JobBank), the corporate brand of Leahcim T. Semaj and Company Limited. Her role is to leverage her experience in business and academia to lead the organisation during this transitional period and beyond.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aboveorbeyondjm.com/|title=Above or Beyond|website=Above or Beyond|access-date=2017-12-09}}</ref>
As a serial entrepreneur, Dr. Palmer has created and led successful businesses over the last two decades in Information Technology, Trucking, Coatings and Luxury Services. She has created a distinct personal brand that makes a real difference in the lives of individuals and organisations she touches.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://aboveorbeyondjm.com/content/partners|title=Partners|last=Palmer|first=Sandra|date=2016-12-23|work=Above or Beyond|access-date=2017-12-09|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
=== Lecturing ===
Palmer began her career in education at [[Jamaica College]] as a teacher of Caribbean History. She left after one semester but would return to education in 2007 when she became a lecturer at the [[University of the West Indies, Mona]] School of Business and Management and also at [[Northern Caribbean University]], College of Business and Hospitality Management.<ref name="Vision" /> At the Mona School of Business and Management at the [[University of the West Indies]] in Jamaica, Palmer redesigned the New Ventures and Entrepreneurship course, in the MBA, MBM, and EMBA programs at the University.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=Ainsworth|title=MSBM students top business plan competition|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/magazines/career/MSBM-students-top-business-plan-competition_14589863#ixzz2XvcjAHEk|accessdate=28 May 2015|publisher=Jamaica Observer|date=June 30, 2013}}</ref> At Northern Caribbean University, she teaches Business Writing, Entrepreneurship and New Venture Initiatives, and Managerial Economics in the MBA program. She also lectured Entrepreneurship at the [[University of Technology]] Jamaica from 2007 – 2014. From 2012 – 2014, she served as Dean of Undergraduate Studies at the University College of the Caribbean and also as the Director of [[Information Services]].
===Author=== Palmer's auto-biography is ''On Seraph Wings: Memoirs of a Country Girl''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Roache|first1=Alicia|title=Young businesswoman shares her struggle in new book|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/Entrepreneur-s-Story|accessdate=28 May 2015|publisher=Jamaica Observer|date=February 21, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=n.a.|title=Book Review - An Easily Enjoyable And Engaging Book|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20100228/arts/arts6.html|accessdate=28 May 2015|publisher=Jamaica Gleaner|date=February 28, 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Palmer, Sandra}} [[Category:Jamaican educators]] [[Category:Jamaican business executives]] [[Category:Motivational speakers]] [[Category:Life coaches]] [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Consultants]]

'''Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus''' was a name used by Roman men during the early Roman Empire. They were descendants of Orfitus who was adopted by Servius Cornelius Scipio, an otherwise unknown member of the [[Patrician (ancient Rome)|patrician branch]] of the [[Cornelia (gens)|Cornelii Scipiones]].
There were at least six members of this family who used this name, all direct male descendants of the earliest known member of this branch, the consul of 51. Except for the first two generations, little is known about any of them.
== Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus (consul 51) == {{Main|Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus (consul 51)}} '''Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus''' was ordinary consul in AD 51 as the colleague of the emperor [[Claudius]]. He was one of the victims of the ''[[delator]]'' [[Marcus Aquilius Regulus]] during the reign of [[Nero]].
== Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus (consul 1st century) == {{Main|Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus (consul 1st century)}} '''Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus''' was a suffect consul in some year prior to 87; his colleague has not been identified. He was the son of the consul of AD 51. He was also a victim of imperial suspicion, and was first banished to an island by the emperor [[Domitian]] then later executed.
== Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus (consul 110) == '''Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus''' was ordinary consul in AD 110 as the colleague of [[Marcus Peducaeus Priscinus]]. He was the son of the previous Orfitus. The only other fact known of his life is that he was [[Urban prefect]] of Rome during the reign of [[Antoninus Pius]].<ref>[[Géza Alföldy]], ''Konsulat und Senatorenstand unter der Antoninen'' (Bonn: Rudolf Habelt Verlag, 1977), p. 287</ref>
== Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus (proconsul of Africa) == '''Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus''' is known through inscriptions to have been [[proconsul]] of [[Africa (Roman province)|Africa]] in 163/164.<ref>{{CIL|8|24}}</ref> From this it can be inferred that this Orfitus was suffect consul around 146. It is assumed he was the son of the consul of 110.
It was assumed at one point that this Orfitus was also the ordinary consul of 149, but more recent research has identified that Orfitus as Lucius Sergius Salvidienus Scipio Orfitus, a member of the ''[[Sergia (gens)|gens Sergia]]''.<ref>[[Werner Eck]], "Die Fasti consulares der Regungszeit des Antoninus Pius, eine Bestandsaufnahme seit Géza Alföldys Konsulat und Senatorenstand" in ''Studia epigraphica in memoriam Géza Alföldy'', hg. W. Eck, B. Feher, and P. Kovács (Bonn, 2013), p.75; James H. Oliver, [http://grbs.library.duke.edu/article/view/9671 "The Solonian Constitution and a Consul of A.D. 149"], ''Greek, Roman and Byzantine Studies'', 13 (1972), pp. 103-107</ref>
== Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus (consul 178) == '''Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus''' was ordinary consul in AD 178 with [[Decimus Velius Rufus]] as his colleague. He is known only through consular dating; it is assumed he was the son of the previous Orfitus.<ref>Alföldy, ''Konsulat und Senatorenstand'', pp. 191, 312</ref>
== Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus (Salii Palatini) == '''Servius Cornelius Scipio Salvidienus Orfitus''' was a member of the ''[[Salii|Salii Palatinii]]'' an ancient Roman priesthood for the years 189 and 190.<ref>{{CIL|6|1980}}, {{CIL|6|1981}}</ref> It is assumed he was the son of the previous Orfitus. There is no record of this Orfitus acceding to the consulate; while this may indicate that he died before the age of 31 or 32, the earliest point a Patrician could be a consul, attestations of suffect consul become much more scarce after 180 and evidence of his consulate simply has yet to be recovered.
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Stephen Jin-Woo Kim''' is a former State Department contractor who pleaded guilty to a felony count of disclosing classified information to [[Fox News]] reporter [[James Rosen (journalist)|James Rosen]].<ref name=GuiltyPlea>{{cite news|last=GERSTEIN|first=JOSH|title=Stephen Kim to plead guilty in Fox News leak case |url=http://www.politico.com/story/2014/02/stephen-kim-james-risen-state-department-fox-news-103265.html|accessdate=7 February 2014|newspaper=Politico|date=7 February 2014}}</ref><ref name=PleaAgreement>{{cite web|title=Re: United States v. Stephen Jin-Woo Kim |url=https://fas.org/sgp/jud/kim/plea.pdf|accessdate=12 June 2016|date=12 June 2016}}</ref> Prosecutors had charged that Kim's actions indirectly alerted [[North Korea]] to what U.S. intelligence officials "knew or did not know about its military capabilities and preparedness."<ref name="washingtonpost.com">https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/ex-state-dept-adviser-stephen-j-kim-sentenced-to-13-months-in-leak-case/2014/04/02/f877be54-b9dd-11e3-96ae-f2c36d2b1245_story.html</ref>
== Early life == He was born on August 15, 1967, in [[Seoul]], [[South Korea]]. His family moved to New York in 1976. He attended [[Fordham Preparatory School]], a Jesuit school. For college he went to the [[Georgetown University]] [[Edmund A. Walsh School of Foreign Service|School of Foreign Service]] (1989). He tried out [[Wall Street]] but found the work did not suit him. Following that, he attended [[Harvard]] for a [[master's degree]] in [[national security]] (1992), and then [[Yale University|Yale]] for a [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] in [[Diplomatic history|diplomatic]] and [[military history]] (1999). He authored a book based on his dissertation.<ref name="creativejunkfood_llc"/><ref name=onesheet/><ref name="creativejunkfood_llc2"/> He has also extensively studied philosophy and literature.<ref name="creativejunkfood_llc"/>
== Employment == After graduation, he went to work at the [[Center for Naval Analyses]], where he analyzed US operations in Kosovo, Afghanistan, and Iraq. After the [[September 11 attacks]], he moved to the [[Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory]] where he focused on [[North Korea]]. He briefed the [[Defense Policy Board]] on his work as well as [[Henry Kissinger]], [[Stephen Hadley]], and [[Dick Cheney]]. He also worked at the [[Office of Net Assessment]] under the [[Secretary of Defense]], analyzing Chinese nuclear issues.<ref name="creativejunkfood_llc"/><ref name="creativejunkfood_llc2"/>
In 2008, he went to work as a contractor at the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] at the [[Bureau of Arms Control, Verification and Compliance]]. There, he was Senior Advisor for Intelligence to the [[Assistant Secretary of State for Verification, Compliance, and Implementation]]. He studied North Korea's nuclear program, especially its claims of dismantling its equipment. He also participated in nuclear [[military simulation|war games]] at the [[Naval War College]].<ref name="creativejunkfood_llc"/><ref name="creativejunkfood_llc2"/><ref name=shane2/>
=== Incident with Rosen === In June 2009,<ref name=shane2/> Kim allegedly had a conversation<ref name="creativejunkfood_llc3"/> with Rosen about North Korea planning a [[nuclear weapons testing|nuclear bomb test]].<ref name="msncom"/>
== Indictment == In August 2010, Kim was indicted by a [[grand jury]] on two charges:<ref name="josh_gerstein"/><ref name=crypt1/>
*Unauthorized disclosure of national defense information in violation of {{uscsub|18|793|d}} (the [[Espionage Act]]) *[[Making false statements]] in violation of {{uscsub|18|1001|a|2}}
The government alleges that Kim's conversation with Rosen contained information related to the "national defense"<ref name=crypt1/><ref name="mark_hosenball"/> (793(d) does not use the word "classified"). The alleged false statements to the FBI occurred in September 2009,<ref name=shane2/> regarding whether or not Kim had any contact with Rosen (whom he allegedly met around March 2009).<ref name=crypt3/>
Kim initially pleaded not guilty.<ref name=shane2/> Rosen and Fox were not named in the indictment (which listed them as a "reporter" and a "news organization"), but news reports identified the parties.<ref name="msncom"/><ref name="mark_hosenball"/>
Kim was defended by prominent attorneys [[Abbe Lowell]] of [[Chadbourne & Parke]] and Paul M. Thompson and James M. Commons of [[McDermott Will & Emery]].<ref name="josh_gerstein"/> One of Lowell's arguments was that [[Bob Woodward]]'s book ''[[Obama's Wars]]'' contains far more sensitive information than the information Kim is accused of leaking, which created a [[double standard]] in leak prosecution.<ref name="msncom"/> Lowell also said that the DOJ is "stretch[ing] the espionage laws" and having a [[chilling effect (law)|chilling effect]] on government officials communicating with the press. He also said that Kim would never do anything "for which he had any reason to believe would harm <nowiki>[US interests]</nowiki>."<ref name="mark_hosenball"/><ref name="washingtonpostcom2010"/>
== Guilty plea ==
On February 7, 2014, Kim entered a guilty plea to a single felony count of disclosing classified national defense information to an unauthorized person, Rosen. His lawyer, Lowell, admitted that his client "made a decision to cross a line" and that he "should have known better." Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Harvey added that Kim "was motivated not by an altruistic purpose but by his own ego and desire for professional advancement." Before sentencing, US District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly said Kim "did lose his moral compass."<ref name="washingtonpost.com"/> Kim was sentenced to a 13-month prison term.<ref name=GuiltyPlea/>
== See also == *[[Thomas Andrews Drake]] (NSA [[whistleblower]] charged under the [[Espionage Act]], 2010) *[[Jeffrey Alexander Sterling]] (ex-CIA convicted under [[Espionage Act]] for revealing classified information to a reporter, 2010)
